headline: President Trump Says He Deliberately Played Down Danger of Coronavirus
text: (WASHINGTON) ‚Äî President Donald Trump talked in private about the ‚Äúdeadly‚Äù coronavirus last February even as he was declaring to America it was no worse than the flu and insisting it was under control according to a new book by journalist Bob Woodward. Trump said Wednesday he was just being a ‚Äúcheerleader‚Äù for the nation and trying to keep everyone calm. His public rhetoric Trump told Woodward in March was part of a strategy to deliberately minimize the danger. ‚ÄúI wanted to always play it down‚Äù the president said. ‚ÄúI still like playing it down because I don‚Äôt want to create a panic.‚Äù Trump according to the book acknowledged being alarmed by the virus even as he was telling the nation that it would swiftly disappear. Coming less than eight weeks before Election Day the revelations in the book ‚Äî accompanied by recordings Woodward made of his interviews with Trump ‚Äî provide an unwelcome return of public attention to the president‚Äôs handling of the pandemic that has so far killed about 190000 Americans. He is currently pushing hard for a resumption of normal activity and trying to project strength and control to bolster his political position in his campaign against Democrat Joe Biden. In a Feb. 7 call with Woodward Trump said of the virus: ‚ÄúYou just breathe the air and that‚Äôs how it‚Äôs passed. And so that‚Äôs a very tricky one. That‚Äôs a very delicate one. It‚Äôs also more deadly than even your strenuous flus.‚Äù ‚ÄúThis is deadly stuff‚Äù the president repeated for emphasis. Just three days later Trump struck a far rosier tone in an interview with Fox Business: ‚ÄúI think the virus is going to be ‚Äî it‚Äôs going to be fine.‚Äù Biden said Wednesday the book shows Trump ‚Äúlied to the American people. He knowingly and willingly lied about the threat it posed to the country for months.‚Äù ‚ÄúWhile a deadly disease ripped through our nation he failed to do his job ‚Äî on purpose. It was a life or death betrayal of the American people‚Äù Biden said at a campaign event in Michigan. Biden‚Äôs campaign pounced releasing an ad late Wednesday featuring the audiotapes of Trump‚Äôs remarks. ‚ÄúAnd Trump knew all along‚Äù the ad‚Äôs narrator says. Speaking Wednesday at the White House Trump acknowledged he downplayed the virus insisting he was trying to buck up the nation and suggesting he was trying to avoid ‚Äúgouging‚Äù on prices of needed supplies. ‚ÄúThe fact is I‚Äôm a cheerleader for this country. I love our country and I don‚Äôt want people to be frightened. I don‚Äôt want to create panic as you say‚Äù Trump told reporters. ‚ÄúCertainly I‚Äôm not going to drive this country or the world into a frenzy. We want to show confidence. We want to show strength.‚Äù Yet Trump‚Äôs public comments suggested he was steering people to ignore the reality of the coming storm. Woodward‚Äôs account details dire warnings from top Trump national security officials to the president in late January that the virus that causes COVID-19 could be as bad as the devastating influenza pandemic of 1918. On Feb. 25 just weeks before much of the country was forced to shut down because of the pandemic Trump declared the virus ‚Äúvery well under control in our country.‚Äù Though he restricted travel from China in January Trump did not begin to devote extensive federal resources to procuring vital personal protective equipment including face masks or expand the production of ventilators until March. In fact U.S. officials recommended against widespread mask wearing until April in part because of a shortage of protective masks required by front-line medical workers. Trump aides and allies said at the time that he was aiming to prop up the economy with his rosy take on the virus throughout February even as his administration took few concrete steps to prepare for the coming pandemic. The Washington Post where Woodward serves as associate editor reported excerpts of the book ‚ÄúRage‚Äù on Wednesday as did CNN. The book also covers race relations diplomacy with North Korea and a range of other issues that have arisen during the past two years. The book is based in part on 18 interviews that Woodward conducted with Trump between December and July. ‚ÄúTrump never did seem willing to fully mobilize the federal government and continually seemed to push problems off on the states‚Äù Woodward writes of the pandemic. ‚ÄúThere was no real management theory of the case or how to organize a massive enterprise to deal with one of the most complex emergencies the United States had ever faced.‚Äù White House press secretary Kayleigh McEnany said Wednesday: ‚ÄúThe president has never lied to the American public on COVID. The president was expressing calm and his actions reflect that.‚Äù She said Trump‚Äôs actions show that he took COVID-19 seriously. She noted that the president put in place travel restrictions with China on Jan. 31 and said that some Democrats had criticized the move. In an interview with Fox News on Wednesday Dr. Anthony Fauci the government‚Äôs top infectious disease expert said Trump never ‚Äúdistorted‚Äù what Fauci had told the president. ‚ÄúOften he would want to you know make sure that the country doesn‚Äôt get down and out about things but I don‚Äôt recall anything that was any gross distortion in things that I spoke to him about‚Äù Fauci said. McEnany insisted ‚Äúthe president never downplayed the virus‚Äù though Trump himself told Woodward he was ‚Äúplaying it down because I don‚Äôt want to create a panic.‚Äù ‚ÄúThere is damning truth that President Trump lied and people died‚Äù said Senate Democratic leader Chuck Schumer of New York. Schumer said that when he thinks about how many people in his state died ‚ÄúIt just makes me angry.‚Äù He added ‚ÄúHow many people would be alive today if he just told Americans the truth?‚Äù House Speaker Nancy Pelosi D-Calif. said the president‚Äôs comments to Woodward showed weakness and a disdain for science. ‚ÄúWhat he was actually saying is ‚ÄòI don‚Äôt want anybody to think anything like this happened on my watch so I‚Äôm not going to call any more attention to it‚Äô‚Äù Pelosi said on MSNBC. Woodward‚Äôs book is his second on the Trump White House. The first published in 2018 portrayed Trump in an unflattering light and the president fumed at staff that he was not interviewed for it according to former White House officials and Republicans close to the White House. They were not authorized to speak publicly about private conversations and discussed the matter on condition of anonymity. Trump was convinced that if he had talked to Woodward it could have led to a more favorable depiction in the book according to the officials. Trump had always held Woodward in high regard ‚Äî he considered the journalist as the biggest star in the field ‚Äî and told aides he must be interviewed if Woodward were to write again the officials said. Several Republican senators at the Capitol declined to comment on the new book telling reporters they hadn‚Äôt yet read it even when informed of key passages about the virus. ‚ÄúI just can‚Äôt can‚Äôt comment on it‚Äù said Sen. Rob Portman R-Ohio. ‚ÄúCould we all have done things differently? Yes including Congress. We were all a little slow to recognize the severity‚Äù Portman said. _____ Associated Press writers Jonathan Lemire in New York Alexandra Jaffe in Warren Michigan and Lisa Mascaro in Washington contributed to this report. Contact us at letters@time.com.

headline: Hoping to Bring Out Conservative Voters Donald Trump Releases New Supreme Court Shortlist
text: In a bid to motivate conservative voters in November President Donald Trump released an updated list of people he would consider for possible future Supreme Court vacancies adding 20 new names to the list including three sitting senators. The 20 new people added to Trump‚Äôs list of names include judges he has appointed to the federal bench during his first term like Gregory Katsas of the D.C. Circuit and Barbara Lagoa of the Eleventh Circuit but it also includes a handful of people who aren‚Äôt federal judges. Republican Senators Ted Cruz of Texas Josh Hawley of Missouri and Tom Cotton of Arkansas are on the new list as well as Trump‚Äôs former Solicitor General Noel Francisco and a current lawyer in Trump‚Äôs White House counsel‚Äôs office Kate Todd. (Minutes after the announcement Hawley tweeted that he has ‚Äúno interest‚Äù in serving on the Supreme Court.) Outside of issues of ‚Äúwar and peace‚Äù Trump said in the Diplomatic Room at the White House on Wednesday ‚Äúthe nomination of a Supreme Court justice is the most important decision an American president can make.‚Äù ‚ÄúOver the next four years America‚Äôs president will choose hundreds of federal judges and in all likelihood one two three and even four Supreme Court justices‚Äù Trump continued. Trump‚Äôs updated list is a continuation of the strategy he pioneered during his run for president in 2016 and a pre-election attempt to stoke some of the voter passion for the federal judiciary on the right that helped propel him to the presidency. At the time Justice Antonin Scalia‚Äôs seat on the Supreme Court was vacant and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell vowed to hold it open until after the election by refusing to consider President Barack Obama‚Äôs nomination of Merrick Garland to fill the seat. To appease Republicans unsure about his conservative bona fides in May 2016 Trump released a list of conservative judges he vowed to choose from to fill Scalia‚Äôs seat if he won the presidency. The gambit worked. National exit polls showed that 21% of voters said the Supreme Court appointment was ‚Äúthe most important factor‚Äù in their decision and those voters favored Trump. Trump eventually chose Justice Neil Gorsuch for the Scalia vacancy. Justice Brett Kavanaugh who replaced Justice Anthony Kennedy in 2018 also came from Trump‚Äôs public list which has now been updated three times. Trump and his allies are hoping his record on nominating and confirming conservative judges to the federal bench will continue to be an important selling point for his campaign and stay front of mind for voters. But this year not only is there no Supreme Court seat open the country is in the midst of the COVID-19 pandemic an economic crisis and a national reckoning with racial injustice and police violence. Even those who work on judicial nominations concede the topic may not inspire voters in 2020 the way it did in 2016. Make sense of what matters in Washington. Sign up for the daily D.C. Brief newsletter. The court has also delivered some recent blows to the Administration. This summer at the conclusion of its 2019-2020 term the Supreme Court enjoyed its highest approval rating in over a decade according to Gallup. But while 60% of Republicans approve of the Supreme Court‚Äôs performance that‚Äôs a 13 percentage point decrease in approval among Republicans from the same time last year. Trump and his administration suffered a series of setbacks in decisions from the nation‚Äôs highest court this year including a July ruling that the president is not immune from subpoenas related to his personal financial records from either congressional investigators or state prosecutors. After an earlier decision he was unhappy with‚Äîin which the court upheld the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program in June ‚ÄîTrump tweeted ‚ÄúDo you get the impression that the Supreme Court doesn‚Äôt like me?‚Äù Still Trump often praises his nominees Gorsuch and Kavanaugh and invokes his record on nominating judges at campaign rallies. Trump has appointed nearly one quarter of all active federal judges in the United States according to Pew Research Center and has appointed more federal appeals court judges than any president at this point in his presidency since Jimmy Carter. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs still a big issue‚Äù says a source familiar with the process. ‚ÄúCertainly for his base for low-propensity conservative voters it‚Äôs still a top three issue.‚Äù In a Pew Research poll conducted July 27-August 2 the top two issues for voters in 2020 were the economy and health care followed by Supreme Court appointments. Sixty-four percent of registered voters said Supreme Court appointments were ‚Äúvery important‚Äù to their vote this fall. Republicans see an opportunity with Trump‚Äôs new Supreme Court list to bring the issue back to the forefront of the campaign. Last presidential election when Scalia‚Äôs seat was open ‚ÄúRepublicans had something to lose‚Äù says Mike Davis founder and president of the Article III Project a 501(c)(4) nonprofit group that supports Trump‚Äôs judicial nominees. Davis says his group and other conservative organizations need to help ‚Äúframe‚Äù the choice for 2020 in a similar way: ‚ÄúWhat conservatives need to understand is that they have a lot to lose in this election if they don‚Äôt show up and vote on the Supreme Court because of court packing schemes‚Äù he says. Some Democrats running for president in the primary had supported adding more Justices to the Supreme Court in order to rebalance the court with Democratic picks. Nominee Joe Biden has said he does not. ‚ÄúI would not get into court packing‚Äù the former Vice President said at a debate last year. ‚ÄúWe add three justices; next time around we lose control they add three justices. We begin to lose any credibility the court has at all.‚Äù Biden‚Äôs running-mate Senator Kamala Harris a member of the Judiciary Committee told Politico last year she was open to the idea. Progressive judicial advocacy groups are determined to make the courts as much of a motivating factor for voters on the left this election cycle as it is for the right. ‚ÄúDonald Trump can‚Äôt simply rerun his 2016 playbook because running on the Supreme Court now means reminding voters of Brett Kavanaugh an historically unpopular justice who already has ruled against abortion rights LGBTQ equality and Dreamers‚Äù says Brian Fallon executive director of liberal judicial group Demand Justice. ‚ÄúMeanwhile Democrats have stepped up their focus on the courts in 2020 from Joe Biden promising to nominate the first Black woman justice to the Democratic National Convention ratifying a history-making call for structural reform.‚Äù The additions to Trump‚Äôs list came from a closely-held process run out of the White House counsel‚Äôs office under Pat Cipollone and Todd according to two sources familiar with the process. White House Chief of Staff Mark Meadows was also involved in the West Wing the sources say. White House Press Secretary Kayleigh McEnany said before Trump‚Äôs announcement that the people on the list were all selected based on similar characteristics that Trump looks for in his judicial picks: ‚ÄúHe wants textualists who believe the words of the statute actually are what they are not subject to interpretation‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúHe wants judges guided by the Constitution.‚Äù During the remarks announcing his list Trump called on Biden to release a list of his own. ‚ÄúHe must release a list of justices for people to properly make a decision as to how they will vote‚Äù Trump said. ‚ÄúIt is very important that he do so.‚Äù Trump warned that ‚Äúthe right to life and our great Second Amendment‚Äù are ‚Äúat risk‚Äù and said Biden would appoint ‚Äúextremely far left‚Äù justices. In June Biden indicated his campaign is putting together a list of African American women who he might consider nominating to the Supreme Court but did not say if or when he would make that list public. Trump and his allies on the right believe judges remain a winning issue for them. ‚ÄúI by no means thinks it‚Äôs the number one election issue but I think anytime he‚Äôs talking about judges it‚Äôs the most unifying thing for Republicans‚Äù says a former Republican Senate staffer who worked on judicial confirmations. ‚ÄúEvery Republican is overall happy with how Trump has done on judges.‚Äù Write to Tessa Berenson at tessa.berenson@time.com.

headline: Kool & the Gang Co-Founder Ronald ‚ÄòKhalis‚Äô Bell Dies at 68
text: (LOS ANGELES) ‚Äî Ronald ‚ÄúKhalis‚Äù Bell a co-founder singer and producer of the group Kool & the Gang has died. He was 68. Bell died at his home in the U.S. Virgin Islands Wednesday morning with his wife by his side publicist Sujata Murthy said. The cause of death has not been released. Kool & the Gang grew from jazz roots in the 1960s to become one of the major groups of the 1970s blending jazz funk R&B and pop. After a brief downturn the group enjoyed a return to stardom in the ‚Äô80s. Bell started the group with his brother Robert ‚ÄúKool‚Äù Bell along with neighborhood friends Dennis ‚ÄúD.T.‚Äù Thomas Robert ‚ÄúSpike‚Äù Mickens Charles Smith George Brown and Ricky West. Kool & the Gang won a Grammy in 1978 for their work on the soundtrack for ‚ÄúSaturday Night Fever.‚Äù The group was honored with a BET Soul Train Lifetime Achievement Award in 2014 and inducted into the Songwriters Hall of Fame four years later. As a self-taught musician Bell created his own signature sound using horn lines bass and synthesizer. Bell wrote and composed some of the group‚Äôs biggest songs including ‚ÄúCelebration‚Äù ‚ÄúCherish‚Äù ‚ÄúJungle Boogie‚Äù and ‚ÄúSummer Madness‚Äù which was used in several films including ‚ÄúRocky‚Äù and ‚ÄúBaby Boy.‚Äù The song was also used in a Nike shoe commercial in 2006 featuring LeBron James. Bell was working on a series of collaborations including a solo endeavor ‚ÄúKool Baby Brotha Band.‚Äù He also had plans of putting together a series of animated shorts called ‚ÄúKool TV‚Äù about their childhood and career. Bell is also survived by 10 children. Murthy said the service for Bell will be private. Contact us at letters@time.com.

headline: Trump Has Always Seen a COVID-19 Vaccine as a Political Bet. Will It Pay Off in Time?
text: Scientists and medical researchers inside President Donald Trump‚Äôs administration have repeatedly told the President that the vaccine won‚Äôt be ready until the end of the year at the earliest. But that‚Äôs not what Trump wants voters to believe.  In a new Trump campaign ad that started running in battleground states a voiceover claims ‚ÄúIn the race for a vaccine the finish line is approaching‚Äù as footage of clear medicine bottles scrolls past with fake labels on them reading ‚ÄúCOVID-19 coronavirus vaccine.‚Äù The 30-second ad airs this week on television stations in North Carolina Georgia Florida Wisconsin Minnesota and Michigan and claims that Trump is restarting the economy shut down by the pandemic while ‚ÄúJoe Biden wants to change that.‚Äù Trump made similar claims during a 20-minute campaign-style speech in front of reporters at the White House on Monday in which he repeatedly attacked the former Vice President and promised to have a vaccine ready before Election Day in an open acknowledgement that the political calendar is shaping the government‚Äôs COVID-19 vaccine timeline. A vaccine is ‚Äúgoing to be done in a very short period of time‚Äîcould even have it during the month of October‚Äù Trump told reporters. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll have a vaccine soon maybe before a special date. You know what date I‚Äôm talking about‚Äù he said in a reference to Nov. 3.  The President‚Äôs willingness to openly mix election politics and the complex science of vaccine development has alarmed the pharmaceutical industry enough that nine cutting-edge drug and biotechnology firms put out a statement Tuesday pledging to only ask the Trump Administration‚Äôs approval for COVID-19 vaccines that have demonstrated ‚Äùsafety and efficacy through a Phase 3 clinical study.‚Äù The same day one of the companies AstraZeneca confirmed it had put its global COVID-19 vaccine study on hold after one person in the trial may have reacted badly to the test dose.  Trump‚Äôs rosy comments and optimistic ads about the prospect for a vaccine a challenging and unpredictable medical endeavor under any circumstance are part of a broader wager that delivering major policy goals before the election including completing 500 miles of border wall and withdrawing more troops from Iraq and Afghanistan will help him at the polls. But they aren‚Äôt new. Even before tests for COVID-19 were widely available Trump has talked about the vaccine as a silver bullet in his administration‚Äôs response to the pandemic. Despite disagreement in Trump‚Äôs inner circle about how loudly to tout the push for a COVID-19 vaccine Trump ignored calls for caution and repeatedly pressured companies and health agencies to speed up trials and approval processes in public and private. ‚ÄúHe got it in his head that we have to have a vaccine‚Äù says a former White House official who doesn‚Äôt think the U.S. will have a widely adopted vaccine by election day and may never get to that goal.  Make sense of what matters in Washington. Sign up for the daily D.C. Brief newsletter. On Feb. 26 when there were just 15 known COVID-19 cases in the U.S. Trump said ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre rapidly developing a vaccine‚Äù and that ‚Äúthe vaccine is coming along well‚Äù before there was little data to support such a claim. Instead he pressed medical executives to make his predictions come true. When he met with the heads of major pharmaceutical companies in the White House on March 2 ostensibly to talk about lowering drug prices Trump hijacked the meeting to demand companies to speed up the creation of a COVID-19 vaccine. The next day speaking to a group of county executives he described the pressure he put on the companies: ‚ÄúI said ‚ÄòDo me a favor: Speed it up. Speed it up.‚Äô And they will. They‚Äôre working really hard and quick.‚Äù Though the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has asked states to prepare facilities to distribute vaccines by Nov. 1 the U.S. government‚Äôs top infectious disease scientist Dr. Anthony Fauci said Tuesday that it‚Äôs ‚Äúunlikely we‚Äôll have a definitive answer‚Äù on an effective vaccine by Nov. 3 and more realistic that a vaccine could be ready by ‚Äúthe end of the year.‚Äù Pharmaceutical companies Moderna and Pfizer are working to enroll patients for vaccine trials by the end of September and it takes time to observe the effects of the vaccine and analyze the results.  It‚Äôs entirely possible that a successful vaccine could take longer than Trump or Fauci‚Äôs estimates or take years to arrive. After more than three decades of work scientists have still not managed to deliver an effective HIV vaccine for example. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre making a mistake by putting so much faith in the vaccines‚Äù the former White House official says and adds the President is falling into a trap to make so many public promises to deliver a vaccine quickly when he has little control over whether one will work. Trump also runs the risk of linking the reopening of the economy to the delivery of a vaccine the former official says. The country should prepare to reopen with mitigation measures even if a vaccine is not in widespread use. ‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs a trap to say we can‚Äôt get the country moving without a vaccine‚Äù the former official says. The pause on Tuesday of pharmaceutical company AstraZeneca‚Äôs global coronavirus vaccine trials is a red flag that developing a vaccine is ‚Äúhard‚Äù the former official notes ‚Äúand we can‚Äôt count on getting a vaccine anytime soon. We should all understand that.‚Äù Trump has pushed to designate huge amounts of money toward vaccine research despite some experts‚Äô opinions that those resources and attention should be focused more on therapies that reduce the lethality of COVID-19 and help people who contract the virus recover more quickly. To get to a vaccine Trump has mobilized Health and Human Services and the Department of Defense to speed up research and work with private companies in an effort called Operation Warp Speed. So far the U.S. has allocated $9 billion to develop potential vaccines and set aside an additional $2.5 billion to cover the cost of vials syringes storage and boost manufacturing when there is a viable dose. White House Press Secretary Kayleigh McEnany denied on Wednesday that Trump‚Äôs political calculations are pushing forward the vaccine timeline. ‚ÄúThe science is guiding the way‚Äù she said. The pause by AstraZeneca backs that up McEnany said adding that the White House timing is about ‚Äúsaving lives‚Äù and ‚Äúnot about the election.‚Äù From the beginning of the pandemic Trump‚Äôs instinct has been to calm Americans and financial markets with his public statements. ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt have to buy so much take it easy just relax‚Äù Trump said on March 16 when many Americans were clearing grocery store shelves of toilet paper flour canned goods and other household staples. Trump told journalist Bob Woodward in an interview on March 19 that he wanted to play down the severity of the virus to keep the public calm. ‚ÄúI wanted to always play it down. I still like playing it down because I don‚Äôt want to create a panic‚Äù Trump told Woodward. Asked by a reporter in the White House on Wednesday if he misled the public about the severity of the virus Trump said ‚ÄúWell I think if you said in order to reduce panic perhaps that‚Äôs so. The fact is I‚Äôm a cheerleader for this country. I love our country and I don‚Äôt want people to be frightened. I don‚Äôt want to create panic.‚Äù But Trump‚Äôs public pressure campaign has created its own waves of anxiety that government scientists will be pushed to release a vaccine that hasn‚Äôt been properly vetted. Speaking Sunday on CNN Kamala Harris raised concerns that scientists will be ‚Äúmuzzled‚Äù and ‚Äúsidelined‚Äù because Trump is looking toward the election ‚Äúand he‚Äôs grasping for whatever he can get to pretend that he has been a leader on this issue when he has not.‚Äù She said she would not take Trump‚Äôs word when deciding whether to get a vaccine produced under his administration‚Äôs supervision. She said she would be looking to a ‚Äúcredible source of information‚Äù like Dr. Fauci the top infectious disease official in the government before deciding to take the vaccine. Trump ‚Äúwants us to inject bleach‚Äù Harris said ‚ÄúNo I will not take his word.‚Äù  All Americans will be facing the same choice.  Contact us at letters@time.com.

headline: U.S. Crime Victims Often Don't Get the Government Money Meant to Help Them Heal‚Äîand Say They Feel 'Excluded'
text: Aswad Thomas‚Äô dream of pursuing a career in basketball was disrupted about a decade ago when he was shot twice in the back during an attempted armed robbery in Connecticut. In the following years Thomas‚Äîlike many other victims of violent crime‚Äîdidn‚Äôt know that Congress had set aside money and resources for his recovery decades ago. Had Thomas known the 37-year-old says he would have been better able to deal with the injury as well as his PTSD by tapping into counseling services physical therapy and relocation support. ‚ÄúI was shot just blocks away from where I live so the fear of going outside was something I struggled with for years‚Äù Thomas says. ‚ÄúI would have loved physical therapy to help me get back on my feet and see if I could continue my basketball career.‚Äù Thomas was 26 when he was shot just three months after he became a first-generation college graduate. The shooting put him in debt since he wasn‚Äôt able to work and didn‚Äôt have the financial stability to pay off his student loans on a monthly basis. ‚ÄúThis has negatively affected my credit history and still continues to be a significant barrier for me and my family‚Äù Thomas says. Fewer than 1 in 3 crime survivors report receiving help‚Äîincluding financial medical and mental health assistance‚Äîduring their recovery according to a new report from the Alliance for Safety and Justice a national organization that advocates for crime victims and improving public safety. The study released Wednesday includes a broad survey conducted in June 2020 of public safety priorities for more than 4000 Americans including 752 crime victims and 511 people convicted of crimes. It notes that 1 in 5 Americans have been victims of a crime over the past decade‚Äîand Black Americans were nearly 25% more likely to have been victims of serious violent crime compared to white Americans in 2018. For crime victims who received help the majority said they received it from hospitals or family and friends according to the study. Fewer relied on the criminal justice system; about 18% said they received help from police and 16% said they received help from prosecutors. According to the study federal reporting indicates millions of people reported being victims of crimes but ‚Äúonly 243000 people had victim compensation applications approved‚Äù in 2018 as part of the landmark 1984 Victims of Crime Act (VOCA) created to provide financial and other forms of assistance to crime survivors. A big issue is that not every crime victim knows that they have access to government support. ‚ÄúThere is not widespread education that these resources exist and that is problematic‚Äù says Fatimah Loren Dreier executive director of The Health Alliance for Violence Intervention a national organization that focuses on hospital-based violence intervention programs. ‚ÄúThere is a lack of clarity about who is responsible for ensuring people are aware of and given access to these resources‚Äù she says. It varies across states. In order to receive money from victim compensation funds individuals have to cooperate and interact with police which in some cases can be a ‚Äúchallenge‚Äù and an ‚Äúunnecessary barrier to receiving care‚Äù Dreier says. To be eligible for official compensation survivors are typically required to report the crime to law enforcement; in some states they must report the incident as quickly as 72 hours after it occurred to be considered for compensation. ‚ÄúFor the patients that we serve who have had really challenging largely horrendous experiences with the criminal justice system trust is very low‚Äù Dreier says. If a police officer decides that a crime victim who may be in a hospital‚Äîtraumatized and sedated‚Äîis uncooperative that could jeopardize an individual‚Äôs eligibility to seek compensation she adds. This ties into a larger debate about the expansive role of policing that has been scrutinized amid nationwide Black Lives Matter protests which have included calls to rethink public safety by redirecting resources and power away from the police. In 2018 40% of individuals who applied for victim compensation benefits after suffering harm as a direct result of a crime and self-reported their ethnicity were white; 26% were Hispanic/Latino and 25% were Black/African-American according to the Office for Victims of Crime. Meg Garvin executive director of the National Crime Victim Law Institute and a clinical professor of law at Lewis & Clark Law School says that in addition to apprehension about dealing with law enforcement‚Äîoften because of past bad experiences or being undocumented‚Äîlanguage barriers if English is not their first language and trauma can also make it harder to access resources. ‚ÄúWe have to figure out a way to increase the ability for survivors to access what they need over the course of their entire lifetime‚Äù Garvin says. Garvin and her team of lawyers guide crime survivors through a maze of regulations to try and secure the support the government promised them. They receive VOCA dollars and train other lawyers to help crime victims navigate the system but ‚Äúright now it‚Äôs band aids not a system of accessible lawyers‚Äù says Garvin who adds that ideally victims of violent crime would be provided with a lawyer at no cost. Garvin says many of the current government resources for crime survivors ‚Äústart from the premise of ‚Äòhere are the things we can give you'‚Äù instead of ‚Äúwhat do you need.‚Äù More than $407 million was paid out in victim compensation in 2018 according to the Office for Victims of Crime a part of the U.S. Department of Justice. The highest proportion of money‚Äî35%‚Äîcovered medical and dental expenses followed by 15% for funeral/burial expenses. Many states that receive federal funding through VOCA which provides supplementary funding for state victim compensation programs as well as money for victims services programs do not spend it all says Dreier. (She says her organization was part of a broad coalition that successfully advocated for $20 million in unused New Jersey VOCA funds to be allocated toward launching hospital-based violence intervention programs in nine cities.) Dr. LaDonna Butler now a mental health counselor and member of Crime Survivors for Safety and Justice a flagship program of Alliance for Safety and Justice says she did not get what she needed after she was sexually assaulted in 1996. Butler says that she was able to access counseling support after her sexual assault but that it was short-term and not comprehensive enough. ‚ÄúThere was a significant disconnect between what I needed and what I received‚Äù Butler says adding that it ‚Äúdelayed (her) healing process.‚Äù ‚ÄúFor too long the people most harmed by the criminal justice system the people most harmed by violence have been the least supported and have been excluded from conversations about safety and public safety‚Äù Thomas says. He is now managing director of Crime Survivors for Safety and Justice which organizes a national network of crime survivors especially young men of color to advocate for local state and federal policies. Crime survivors like Thomas and Butler say their vision of safety includes investing in programs that provide violence intervention and mental health support. ‚ÄúIf it‚Äôs not making us all safer then policymakers should not be funding it‚Äù Butler says. Most of those surveyed by the Alliance for Safety and Justice supported a shift away from prioritizing funds for prisons and jails. Instead they support focusing on prevention mental health and reentry to help the formerly incarcerated transition back into their communities‚Äîwith about 80% supporting federal investments to increase the use of community-based violence prevention workers to prevent crime. ‚ÄúOver-incarceration did not keep me safe. It did not get the person who assaulted me any support or treatment‚Äù Butler says. ‚ÄúThere was no rehabilitation inside of jail. It did not result in him coming out better. He came out worse.‚Äù Thomas also advocates for law enforcement to proactively educate victims about the resources available to them. He says officers frequently visited him after he was shot but never informed him of the funds that might have helped him when he needed them most. ‚ÄúEvery time they visited it was always about the case‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúNot one time did they ask me if I needed any support services they never told me about the victim compensation program.‚Äù Write to Sanya Mansoor at sanya.mansoor@time.com.

headline: Hoping to Bring Out Conservative Voters Donald Trump Releases New Supreme Court Shortlist
text: In a bid to motivate conservative voters in November President Donald Trump released an updated list of people he would consider for possible future Supreme Court vacancies adding 20 new names to the list including three sitting senators. The 20 new people added to Trump‚Äôs list of names include judges he has appointed to the federal bench during his first term like Gregory Katsas of the D.C. Circuit and Barbara Lagoa of the Eleventh Circuit but it also includes a handful of people who aren‚Äôt federal judges. Republican Senators Ted Cruz of Texas Josh Hawley of Missouri and Tom Cotton of Arkansas are on the new list as well as Trump‚Äôs former Solicitor General Noel Francisco and a current lawyer in Trump‚Äôs White House counsel‚Äôs office Kate Todd. (Minutes after the announcement Hawley tweeted that he has ‚Äúno interest‚Äù in serving on the Supreme Court.) Outside of issues of ‚Äúwar and peace‚Äù Trump said in the Diplomatic Room at the White House on Wednesday ‚Äúthe nomination of a Supreme Court justice is the most important decision an American president can make.‚Äù ‚ÄúOver the next four years America‚Äôs president will choose hundreds of federal judges and in all likelihood one two three and even four Supreme Court justices‚Äù Trump continued. Trump‚Äôs updated list is a continuation of the strategy he pioneered during his run for president in 2016 and a pre-election attempt to stoke some of the voter passion for the federal judiciary on the right that helped propel him to the presidency. At the time Justice Antonin Scalia‚Äôs seat on the Supreme Court was vacant and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell vowed to hold it open until after the election by refusing to consider President Barack Obama‚Äôs nomination of Merrick Garland to fill the seat. To appease Republicans unsure about his conservative bona fides in May 2016 Trump released a list of conservative judges he vowed to choose from to fill Scalia‚Äôs seat if he won the presidency. The gambit worked. National exit polls showed that 21% of voters said the Supreme Court appointment was ‚Äúthe most important factor‚Äù in their decision and those voters favored Trump. Trump eventually chose Justice Neil Gorsuch for the Scalia vacancy. Justice Brett Kavanaugh who replaced Justice Anthony Kennedy in 2018 also came from Trump‚Äôs public list which has now been updated three times. Trump and his allies are hoping his record on nominating and confirming conservative judges to the federal bench will continue to be an important selling point for his campaign and stay front of mind for voters. But this year not only is there no Supreme Court seat open the country is in the midst of the COVID-19 pandemic an economic crisis and a national reckoning with racial injustice and police violence. Even those who work on judicial nominations concede the topic may not inspire voters in 2020 the way it did in 2016. Make sense of what matters in Washington. Sign up for the daily D.C. Brief newsletter. The court has also delivered some recent blows to the Administration. This summer at the conclusion of its 2019-2020 term the Supreme Court enjoyed its highest approval rating in over a decade according to Gallup. But while 60% of Republicans approve of the Supreme Court‚Äôs performance that‚Äôs a 13 percentage point decrease in approval among Republicans from the same time last year. Trump and his administration suffered a series of setbacks in decisions from the nation‚Äôs highest court this year including a July ruling that the president is not immune from subpoenas related to his personal financial records from either congressional investigators or state prosecutors. After an earlier decision he was unhappy with‚Äîin which the court upheld the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program in June ‚ÄîTrump tweeted ‚ÄúDo you get the impression that the Supreme Court doesn‚Äôt like me?‚Äù Still Trump often praises his nominees Gorsuch and Kavanaugh and invokes his record on nominating judges at campaign rallies. Trump has appointed nearly one quarter of all active federal judges in the United States according to Pew Research Center and has appointed more federal appeals court judges than any president at this point in his presidency since Jimmy Carter. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs still a big issue‚Äù says a source familiar with the process. ‚ÄúCertainly for his base for low-propensity conservative voters it‚Äôs still a top three issue.‚Äù In a Pew Research poll conducted July 27-August 2 the top two issues for voters in 2020 were the economy and health care followed by Supreme Court appointments. Sixty-four percent of registered voters said Supreme Court appointments were ‚Äúvery important‚Äù to their vote this fall. Republicans see an opportunity with Trump‚Äôs new Supreme Court list to bring the issue back to the forefront of the campaign. Last presidential election when Scalia‚Äôs seat was open ‚ÄúRepublicans had something to lose‚Äù says Mike Davis founder and president of the Article III Project a 501(c)(4) nonprofit group that supports Trump‚Äôs judicial nominees. Davis says his group and other conservative organizations need to help ‚Äúframe‚Äù the choice for 2020 in a similar way: ‚ÄúWhat conservatives need to understand is that they have a lot to lose in this election if they don‚Äôt show up and vote on the Supreme Court because of court packing schemes‚Äù he says. Some Democrats running for president in the primary had supported adding more Justices to the Supreme Court in order to rebalance the court with Democratic picks. Nominee Joe Biden has said he does not. ‚ÄúI would not get into court packing‚Äù the former Vice President said at a debate last year. ‚ÄúWe add three justices; next time around we lose control they add three justices. We begin to lose any credibility the court has at all.‚Äù Biden‚Äôs running-mate Senator Kamala Harris a member of the Judiciary Committee told Politico last year she was open to the idea. Progressive judicial advocacy groups are determined to make the courts as much of a motivating factor for voters on the left this election cycle as it is for the right. ‚ÄúDonald Trump can‚Äôt simply rerun his 2016 playbook because running on the Supreme Court now means reminding voters of Brett Kavanaugh an historically unpopular justice who already has ruled against abortion rights LGBTQ equality and Dreamers‚Äù says Brian Fallon executive director of liberal judicial group Demand Justice. ‚ÄúMeanwhile Democrats have stepped up their focus on the courts in 2020 from Joe Biden promising to nominate the first Black woman justice to the Democratic National Convention ratifying a history-making call for structural reform.‚Äù The additions to Trump‚Äôs list came from a closely-held process run out of the White House counsel‚Äôs office under Pat Cipollone and Todd according to two sources familiar with the process. White House Chief of Staff Mark Meadows was also involved in the West Wing the sources say. White House Press Secretary Kayleigh McEnany said before Trump‚Äôs announcement that the people on the list were all selected based on similar characteristics that Trump looks for in his judicial picks: ‚ÄúHe wants textualists who believe the words of the statute actually are what they are not subject to interpretation‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúHe wants judges guided by the Constitution.‚Äù During the remarks announcing his list Trump called on Biden to release a list of his own. ‚ÄúHe must release a list of justices for people to properly make a decision as to how they will vote‚Äù Trump said. ‚ÄúIt is very important that he do so.‚Äù Trump warned that ‚Äúthe right to life and our great Second Amendment‚Äù are ‚Äúat risk‚Äù and said Biden would appoint ‚Äúextremely far left‚Äù justices. In June Biden indicated his campaign is putting together a list of African American women who he might consider nominating to the Supreme Court but did not say if or when he would make that list public. Trump and his allies on the right believe judges remain a winning issue for them. ‚ÄúI by no means thinks it‚Äôs the number one election issue but I think anytime he‚Äôs talking about judges it‚Äôs the most unifying thing for Republicans‚Äù says a former Republican Senate staffer who worked on judicial confirmations. ‚ÄúEvery Republican is overall happy with how Trump has done on judges.‚Äù Write to Tessa Berenson at tessa.berenson@time.com.

headline: Trump Has Always Seen a COVID-19 Vaccine as a Political Bet. Will It Pay Off in Time?
text: Scientists and medical researchers inside President Donald Trump‚Äôs administration have repeatedly told the President that the vaccine won‚Äôt be ready until the end of the year at the earliest. But that‚Äôs not what Trump wants voters to believe.  In a new Trump campaign ad that started running in battleground states a voiceover claims ‚ÄúIn the race for a vaccine the finish line is approaching‚Äù as footage of clear medicine bottles scrolls past with fake labels on them reading ‚ÄúCOVID-19 coronavirus vaccine.‚Äù The 30-second ad airs this week on television stations in North Carolina Georgia Florida Wisconsin Minnesota and Michigan and claims that Trump is restarting the economy shut down by the pandemic while ‚ÄúJoe Biden wants to change that.‚Äù Trump made similar claims during a 20-minute campaign-style speech in front of reporters at the White House on Monday in which he repeatedly attacked the former Vice President and promised to have a vaccine ready before Election Day in an open acknowledgement that the political calendar is shaping the government‚Äôs COVID-19 vaccine timeline. A vaccine is ‚Äúgoing to be done in a very short period of time‚Äîcould even have it during the month of October‚Äù Trump told reporters. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll have a vaccine soon maybe before a special date. You know what date I‚Äôm talking about‚Äù he said in a reference to Nov. 3.  The President‚Äôs willingness to openly mix election politics and the complex science of vaccine development has alarmed the pharmaceutical industry enough that nine cutting-edge drug and biotechnology firms put out a statement Tuesday pledging to only ask the Trump Administration‚Äôs approval for COVID-19 vaccines that have demonstrated ‚Äùsafety and efficacy through a Phase 3 clinical study.‚Äù The same day one of the companies AstraZeneca confirmed it had put its global COVID-19 vaccine study on hold after one person in the trial may have reacted badly to the test dose.  Trump‚Äôs rosy comments and optimistic ads about the prospect for a vaccine a challenging and unpredictable medical endeavor under any circumstance are part of a broader wager that delivering major policy goals before the election including completing 500 miles of border wall and withdrawing more troops from Iraq and Afghanistan will help him at the polls. But they aren‚Äôt new. Even before tests for COVID-19 were widely available Trump has talked about the vaccine as a silver bullet in his administration‚Äôs response to the pandemic. Despite disagreement in Trump‚Äôs inner circle about how loudly to tout the push for a COVID-19 vaccine Trump ignored calls for caution and repeatedly pressured companies and health agencies to speed up trials and approval processes in public and private. ‚ÄúHe got it in his head that we have to have a vaccine‚Äù says a former White House official who doesn‚Äôt think the U.S. will have a widely adopted vaccine by election day and may never get to that goal.  Make sense of what matters in Washington. Sign up for the daily D.C. Brief newsletter. On Feb. 26 when there were just 15 known COVID-19 cases in the U.S. Trump said ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre rapidly developing a vaccine‚Äù and that ‚Äúthe vaccine is coming along well‚Äù before there was little data to support such a claim. Instead he pressed medical executives to make his predictions come true. When he met with the heads of major pharmaceutical companies in the White House on March 2 ostensibly to talk about lowering drug prices Trump hijacked the meeting to demand companies to speed up the creation of a COVID-19 vaccine. The next day speaking to a group of county executives he described the pressure he put on the companies: ‚ÄúI said ‚ÄòDo me a favor: Speed it up. Speed it up.‚Äô And they will. They‚Äôre working really hard and quick.‚Äù Though the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has asked states to prepare facilities to distribute vaccines by Nov. 1 the U.S. government‚Äôs top infectious disease scientist Dr. Anthony Fauci said Tuesday that it‚Äôs ‚Äúunlikely we‚Äôll have a definitive answer‚Äù on an effective vaccine by Nov. 3 and more realistic that a vaccine could be ready by ‚Äúthe end of the year.‚Äù Pharmaceutical companies Moderna and Pfizer are working to enroll patients for vaccine trials by the end of September and it takes time to observe the effects of the vaccine and analyze the results.  It‚Äôs entirely possible that a successful vaccine could take longer than Trump or Fauci‚Äôs estimates or take years to arrive. After more than three decades of work scientists have still not managed to deliver an effective HIV vaccine for example. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre making a mistake by putting so much faith in the vaccines‚Äù the former White House official says and adds the President is falling into a trap to make so many public promises to deliver a vaccine quickly when he has little control over whether one will work. Trump also runs the risk of linking the reopening of the economy to the delivery of a vaccine the former official says. The country should prepare to reopen with mitigation measures even if a vaccine is not in widespread use. ‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs a trap to say we can‚Äôt get the country moving without a vaccine‚Äù the former official says. The pause on Tuesday of pharmaceutical company AstraZeneca‚Äôs global coronavirus vaccine trials is a red flag that developing a vaccine is ‚Äúhard‚Äù the former official notes ‚Äúand we can‚Äôt count on getting a vaccine anytime soon. We should all understand that.‚Äù Trump has pushed to designate huge amounts of money toward vaccine research despite some experts‚Äô opinions that those resources and attention should be focused more on therapies that reduce the lethality of COVID-19 and help people who contract the virus recover more quickly. To get to a vaccine Trump has mobilized Health and Human Services and the Department of Defense to speed up research and work with private companies in an effort called Operation Warp Speed. So far the U.S. has allocated $9 billion to develop potential vaccines and set aside an additional $2.5 billion to cover the cost of vials syringes storage and boost manufacturing when there is a viable dose. White House Press Secretary Kayleigh McEnany denied on Wednesday that Trump‚Äôs political calculations are pushing forward the vaccine timeline. ‚ÄúThe science is guiding the way‚Äù she said. The pause by AstraZeneca backs that up McEnany said adding that the White House timing is about ‚Äúsaving lives‚Äù and ‚Äúnot about the election.‚Äù From the beginning of the pandemic Trump‚Äôs instinct has been to calm Americans and financial markets with his public statements. ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt have to buy so much take it easy just relax‚Äù Trump said on March 16 when many Americans were clearing grocery store shelves of toilet paper flour canned goods and other household staples. Trump told journalist Bob Woodward in an interview on March 19 that he wanted to play down the severity of the virus to keep the public calm. ‚ÄúI wanted to always play it down. I still like playing it down because I don‚Äôt want to create a panic‚Äù Trump told Woodward. Asked by a reporter in the White House on Wednesday if he misled the public about the severity of the virus Trump said ‚ÄúWell I think if you said in order to reduce panic perhaps that‚Äôs so. The fact is I‚Äôm a cheerleader for this country. I love our country and I don‚Äôt want people to be frightened. I don‚Äôt want to create panic.‚Äù But Trump‚Äôs public pressure campaign has created its own waves of anxiety that government scientists will be pushed to release a vaccine that hasn‚Äôt been properly vetted. Speaking Sunday on CNN Kamala Harris raised concerns that scientists will be ‚Äúmuzzled‚Äù and ‚Äúsidelined‚Äù because Trump is looking toward the election ‚Äúand he‚Äôs grasping for whatever he can get to pretend that he has been a leader on this issue when he has not.‚Äù She said she would not take Trump‚Äôs word when deciding whether to get a vaccine produced under his administration‚Äôs supervision. She said she would be looking to a ‚Äúcredible source of information‚Äù like Dr. Fauci the top infectious disease official in the government before deciding to take the vaccine. Trump ‚Äúwants us to inject bleach‚Äù Harris said ‚ÄúNo I will not take his word.‚Äù  All Americans will be facing the same choice.  Contact us at letters@time.com.

headline: Les deux-tiers de la faune sauvage ont disparu en moins de 50 ans selon le WWF

headline: ‚ÄòBlood spurting‚Äô: Teen bitten on the penis by snake while sitting on the toilet
text: A teenager was rushed to hospital after a 1.2m python bit his penis while he was on the toilet leaving ‚Äúblood spurting everywhere‚Äù. A teenager was rushed to hospital after a python bit his penis while he was on the toilet. A teenager from Thailand was rushed to hospital after he was bitten on the penis by a python that was hiding in the toilet. Picture: Viral PressSource:Viral Press A teenager was rushed to hospital after a 1.2m python hiding in the toilet bit his penis leaving ‚Äúblood spurting everywhere‚Äù. Siraphop Masukarat 18 went to the loo yesterday evening when he felt a sudden searing pain in his manhood. He looked down and saw the python with its jaws clamped around the tip of his penis. Siraphop said he screamed in terror during the incident in Nonthaburi central Thailand about 20km north of Bangkok The Sun reports. He was rushed to nearby Bang Yai Hospital so his injuries could be treated. A teenager from Thailand was rushed to hospital after he was bitten on the penis by a python inside his toilet. Picture: Viral PressSource:Viral Press Doctors gave Siraphop three stitches in the glans at the tip of the penis and treated the bite wound with antibiotic wash to kill any bacteria from the python‚Äôs fangs. ‚ÄúI was using the toilet but a few moments after I sat down I suddenly felt pain in my penis. ‚ÄúI looked down and saw there was a snake hanging in the toilet‚Äù Siraphop said. ‚ÄúThen there was blood everywhere. It was only a small snake but its bite was so strong. ‚ÄúI hope that my penis can recover.‚Äô‚Äô Animal handlers arrived at the two-storey home and began searching for the snake which was still coiled up in the toilet bowl. They used snake catching equipment to snare the python. They put it into a sack before releasing it back into woodland. Siraphop Masukarat 18 has to get multiple stitches as a result of the bite. Picture: Viral PressSource:Viral Press Siraphop said there was ‚Äòblood spurting everywhere‚Äô. Picture: Viral PressSource:Viral Press Siraphop‚Äôs terrified mother Sutapath said she was still shocked about the incident. ‚ÄùI don‚Äôt know how the snake got into my house. It could have been through the drain connected to the toilet‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI know the snake really hurt my son but I‚Äôm relieved it was only a non-venomous python. ‚ÄúIf it was a cobra he would be dead. He will be scared every time he goes to toilet. ‚ÄúBut he‚Äôs recovering well at the hospital and I‚Äôm thankful to the rescue volunteers for catching the snake.‚Äô‚Äô This article originally appeared on The Sun and has been republished with permission. headline: Curtis Scott: Footage of NRL star being tasered by police revealed as all charges dismissed
text: Shocking footage of NRL star Curtis Scott being pepper sprayed and tasered by police has been played in court as charges against him were dismissed. Footage of NRL star Curtis Scott's dramatic arrest in Sydney including him being tasered by police has emerged in court as his charges were dismissed. Bodycam CCTV of Curtis Scott being arrested. Picture: Handout via NCA NewsWireSource:NCA NewsWire Dramatic footage of NRL star Curtis Scott being tasered by police has been played in court a day after a series of charges laid against him following boozy Anzac Day celebrations were sensationally dropped. Extended vision of what Scott‚Äôs lawyer claims was an ‚Äúunreasonable or unlawful‚Äù arrest underpins an application for NSW Police to pay the costs of his nine-month legal battle that total more than $100000. Magistrate Jennifer Giles accepted his guilty plea to other minor charges on Thursday but did not record a conviction. She told Downing Centre Local Court no punishment she handed down could match the events of his arrest. ‚ÄúMy client is innocent and we had to fight pretty hard and pretty long to get this decision‚Äù Scott‚Äôs lawyer Sam Macedone said outside court. Curtis Scott‚Äôs remaining charges were dismissed on Thursday. Picture: NCA NewsWire/Joel CarrettSource:News Corp Australia Scott told reporters the ordeal had been a ‚Äúreally tough time in my life‚Äù that he was hoping to put behind him although Mr Macedone said they would explore bringing a civil case against the police. It came after serious allegations of assaulting and resisting police were dropped in court on Wednesday when the first snippets of revelatory police bodycam footage showed the incident for the first time. The Canberra Raiders outside back was intoxicated and barely conscious as he was arrested just metres from NRL headquarters in Moore Park about 2.10am on January 27. How police found Curtis Scott. Picture: Handout via NCA NewsWireSource:NCA NewsWire Scott is tasered by a police officer.Source:Supplied The view from behind the taser as captured by a police body-worn camera.Source:Supplied In the extended footage played on Thursday Scott 22 was doused with capsicum spray and tasered after police found him sleeping peacefully on his back at the base of a fig tree. The clearly confused footballer can be heard telling police he was ‚Äúgetting dressed‚Äù before changing to a repeated line of ‚ÄúI‚Äôve done nothing wrong‚Äù after he was handcuffed and ordered to get to his feet. It then shows one officer deploy his taser as Scott remains on the ground handcuffed and moaning in pain after copping pepper spray in the face having resisted efforts to stand him up. ‚ÄúStop otherwise you‚Äôll be tasered‚Äù he was warned. Scott writhes and screams out in agony before falling silent when Senior Constable Chris Bucknell tells him: ‚ÄúYou lash out again I‚Äôll f***ing taser you again.‚Äù Curtis Scott recoils after being pepper sprayed.Source:Supplied Sam Macedone said he would speak to his client about a possible civil case. Picture: NCA NewsWire/Bianca De MarchiSource:News Corp Australia The footage revealed Scott was asleep when police first came across him. They tried to rouse him by pinching his ear before handcuffing him without formally placing him under arrest. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt resist mate‚Äù one of the officers says as Scott lays slumped in the roots of a fig tree his eyes closed. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve done thing wrong‚Äù Scott says before being told he is trespassing. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve done f**k all wrong.‚Äù The young rugby league star decided to leave the room on Thursday before the videos were played to the court. Mr Macedone said the ‚Äúgruesome‚Äù incident had taken a big toll on Scott. Prosecutor Sergeant Rebecca Becroft had argued against the footage being played beyond the point it was on Wednesday which did not include Scott‚Äôs tasering a move Mr Macedone later described as an attempt to ‚Äúavoid scrutiny‚Äù. The police case collapsed yesterday after Ms Giles described the police argument that the officers were within their rights to handcuff an unconscious man as ‚Äúa very long and frightening bow‚Äù. Sgt Becroft withdrew five charges on Wednesday two of assaulting police one of resisting arrest and another of indecent behaviour. Curtis Scott after playing for the Canberra Raiders. Picture: Matt Roberts/Getty ImagesSource:Getty Images But Sgt Becroft on Thursday asked Ms Giles how else police were supposed to move on a person she claimed was ‚Äúabsolutely tragically affected by drugs or alcohol‚Äù. She said the officers could have ended up in the Coroner‚Äôs Court if they left him to continue his slumber pondering whether Scott could have choked on his own vomit got into a fight or fell out onto the roadway and been hit by a car. The officers didn‚Äôt go in with ‚Äúguns blazing‚Äù she said and gave him ‚Äúample opportunity to get up and get out of there‚Äù. ‚ÄúAt the time police were acting on the circumstances they were faced with‚Äù Sgt Becroft said. She said police were being asked to foot the bill for hundreds of dollars in costs Scott‚Äôs lawyers racked up in emails and phone calls to the NRL Canberra coach Ricky Stuart and chief executive Don Furner. The costs bill also included a $3300 claim for his legal team studying US websites about tasering Sgt Becroft told the court. Curtis Scott (left) and lawyer Sam Macedone speak to media. Picture: NCA NewsWire/Bianca De MarchiSource:News Corp Australia Separate footage of Scott‚Äôs drunken night through the streets of Paddington before he settled to sleep in Moore Park was also played to the court. Scott was sentenced for two counts of offensive behaviour in public having pleaded guilty to those charges at an earlier court date. No conviction was recorded. CCTV showed him kick and stomp on a bicycle chained to a pole on Regent St. The court heard that came before he punched the driver‚Äôs side door of a taxi and threw his mobile phone at a passing Suzuki Swift. Mr Macedone said Scott had been drinking at the Ivy in Sydney‚Äôs CBD and had no recollection of how he got to Moore Park. He had not drunk for five months and was mentoring the Canberra Raiders under-16 team about the impact of alcohol the court heard. An officer speaks to Scott in the bodycam footage. Picture: Handout via NCA NewsWireSource:NCA NewsWire In dismissing the charges Ms Giles said Scott had already been punished by the intense media scrutiny surrounding the incident and stress at possibly losing his career ‚ÄúYou are clearly a smart person Mr Scott you are the kind of person on whom this experience has not been wasted‚Äù she said ‚ÄúBeing capsicum sprayed whilst you are handcuffed and not decontaminated for some 19-odd minutes that‚Äôs much worse than anything I can do to you.‚Äù Ms Giles will deliver he decision on the costs application on September 25. headline: Concerns for ABC News reporter Michael Rennie after on-air incident
text: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll get our bosses to make sure he‚Äôs OK‚Äù: ABC viewers were stunned this morning as a new reporter appeared to suffer a dramatic decline.  Reporter Michael Rennie appeared to suffer a worrying incident while reporting live on-air. ABC News Queensland Reporter Michael Rennie.Source:ABC An ABC News reporter appeared to suffer a worrying incident while reporting live on-air this morning. ABC‚Äôs new Queensland Reporter Michael Rennie was reporting live from outside JBS beef processing plant in Ipswich this morning when he appeared to falter losing his train of thought and becoming unable to talk. Michael Rennie appeared unable to continue.Source:ABC Rennie wiped his brow as the cameras cut away.Source:ABC ABC host Joe O‚ÄôBrien took over as Rennie struggled: ‚ÄúOK. We‚Äôll leave it there for the moment. Michael Rennie reporting there from Ipswich. We‚Äôll just make sure Michael is OK there. Um so we‚Äôll get the cameraman to check on Michael and we‚Äôll get our bosses there right away to make sure he‚Äôs OK‚Äù he assured viewers. ABC host Joe O'Brien reacts.Source:ABC One viewer watching live described the incident on social media: ‚ÄúHe started talking a bit strangely like he‚Äôd lost his place then when they crossed back to check he didn‚Äôt seem able to talk. I think he might have become emotional which is totally understandable but I hope it wasn‚Äôt a medical issue‚Äù she wrote.  Rennie who made his debut as ABC News‚Äô Queensland Reporter on Monday last week was reporting from Australia‚Äôs largest meat processing facility where 600 jobs had been lost. The meatworks is one of Ipswich‚Äôs biggest employers and has been closed for the past two weeks. Those who were watching live took to social media to ask whether Rennie was OK with one speculating he might be suffering a heart attack and another saying he was ‚Äúworried for the poor bugger‚Äù: Watching ABC NEWS 24. Is that reporter OK? That didn‚Äôt look good. I hope he‚Äôs all right. Hope Michael the reporter on @abcnews is ok?@JoeABCNews üôå‚ù§Ô∏è @ABCaustralia @abcnews @JoeABCNews Is that reporter from QLD reporting on the meat plant job losses okay? @abcnews Qld reporter on tv just now - is he having a heart attack on live tv ???? Better check on him immediately What was up with that @abcnews reporter?Was he crying? @abcnews hope your reporter is ok. Fingers crossed. Just saw it and am worried for the poor bugger.üôèü§û‚ù§ Shortly afterwards O‚ÄôBrien addressed the ‚Äúreally concerning‚Äù incident. ‚ÄúNow just before we move on that was really concerning seeing our reporter Michael Rennie there having some issues when he was doing that report... I want to assure our viewers that we‚Äôre chasing that up right away and getting on top of that and making sure that Michael gets the support he needs at this moment‚Äù he said. Later in the news broadcast O‚ÄôBrien gave viewers another update on the incident saying Rennie was ‚ÄúOK‚Äù. ‚ÄúNow I just want to assure our viewers that our reporter Michael Rennie is OK. We were having a chat to him in the last 5 or 10 minutes or so and he wasn‚Äôt able to continue. Yeah we were a bit concerned about him but he is OK. And we look forward to having a chat to him again soon‚Äù he said. In a statement provided to news.com.au this morning an ABC spokesperson thanked viewers for their concern and said that ‚ÄúMichael is fine. He felt a bit dehydrated and had a moment where he became light-headed and lost his train of thought. He‚Äôs gone home for a rest today and we expect him back tomorrow.‚Äù Rennie himself also assured viewers he was ‚Äúfine‚Äù: Thanks for all the concern about what happened on ABC news channel this morning. I was dehydrated and lost my train of thought. But I‚Äôm fine and I‚Äôll be back at work tomorrow. Cheers Viewers also flooded Rennie‚Äôs most recent tweet from before the broadcast this morning with supportive comments: Hoping you‚Äôre ok - you‚Äôve been doing a great job! ‚ÄúHoping you‚Äôre OK ‚Äì you‚Äôve been doing a great job!‚Äù wrote one viewer. ‚ÄúTake care of yourself Michael ‚Ä¶ you‚Äôre doing a tough job ‚Ä¶ I admire you‚Äù said another. headline: Surfer with COVID-19 arrested at Spanish beach after breaking quarantine
text: A woman with COVID-19 has been arrested on a beach after she allegedly defied quarantine orders and went for a surf instead. A woman with COVID-19 has been arrested after she allegedly defied quarantine orders and went for a surf. The woman was arrested for after breaking quarantine rules after testing positive for coronavirus.Source:Twitter A woman infected with COVID-19 took her son to school and then went for a surf at a beach where she was dramatically arrested police said.  The woman was put in handcuffs and led away by police in hazmat suits on La Zurriola beach in one of Spain‚Äôs top tourist hot spots San Sebastian for allegedly breaching quarantine rules after she tested positive for the virus. RELATED: Follow the latest coronavirus updates RELATED: Loophole to travel freely across Australia She was also believed to have dropped off her five-year-old son off at school before going to the beach. The woman was arrested for after breaking quarantine rules after testing positive for coronavirus.Source:Twitter Pictures show how police raced to get the woman out of the water. ‚ÄúThe police arrived and the woman was in the water for another 15 to 20 minutes before they managed to get her out‚Äù a witness told Spanish media. ‚ÄúI could hear how they were telling her ‚Äòyou have tested positive for coronavirus and you have to leave the water‚Äô. ‚ÄúInstead of heading back to the shoreline she went swimming to a different area‚Äù. Police raced to get the woman out of the water at the beach which is popular with tourists.Source:Twitter The witness claims the woman initially refused to put on her face mask prompting one of the police officers to ‚Äúput his baton in the air‚Äù. So far the school of the unnamed woman‚Äôs child has not yet been revealed and health officials have not issued any comments on the matter. San Sebastian mayor Eneko Goia said the woman‚Äôs actions were ‚Äúirresponsible‚Äù. ‚ÄúIf we‚Äôre speaking about this today it‚Äôs because she‚Äôs an exception to the rule‚Äù he said. According to local reports the woman worked as a lifeguard at San Sebastian‚Äôs La Concha beach in the summer. The woman is believed to have taken her young son to school despite testing positive to COVID-19.Source:Twitter Her colleagues were the ones who contacted the police after noticing her in the water. She was held on suspicion of disobedience after reportedly ignoring officers who had ordered her out of the water for several minutes before finally heading back to shore. The woman is expected to be slapped with a fine of up to around $10000 for breaching quarantine rules. If it emerges that her actions led to another person being infected with the virus she could face a fine of more than $180000. headline: Queensland borders: Daughter not allowed to attend father‚Äôs funeral
text: The PM has revealed what he spoke about with a grieving daughter banned from her dad‚Äôs funeral forced to view his body in PPE. Scott Morrison has made an emotional plea for the Queensland Premier to allow a 26-year-old daughter to attend her father‚Äôs funeral today during a tearful radio interview. Sarah Caisip missed her father‚Äôs funeral because she could only view his body. Picture: SuppliedSource:Facebook A grieving daughter who was banned from attending her father‚Äôs funeral was surrounded by security guards and dressed in full PPE gear to say her last goodbye. Canberran Sarah Caisip 26 was trapped in quarantine in Queensland and was taken under police escort Thursday to see her father‚Äôs body. She was not able to attend the service. The heartbreaking ‚Äúsolution‚Äù to a bitter row over the plight of the family was announced by Queensland Health after a war of words between the Prime Minister and the Queensland Premier. Sarah went and said goodbye to her dad's body today.Source:Channel 9 Prime Minister Scott Morrison raised the issue with Peta Credlin on Sky News Thursday night saying he spoke to Ms Caisip over the phone. ‚ÄúShe sent me a lovely message. But that just I think just shows the generosity of her spirit on a just what must have been the most horrible of days for her. I‚Äôve seen the images of when she went to see her dad and there‚Äôve been some shocking days during the course of this pandemic. And today was today just hurt‚Äù the PM said. ‚ÄúAnd it‚Äôs not just about Sarah‚Äôs case because there are others. ‚ÄúYou know we‚Äôve got to find if these things have got to be up if that‚Äôs the view they got to find a better way. ‚ÄúThose who have decided these measures are necessary that they‚Äôve got to find a better way to deal with with the heart here. ‚ÄúI mean I‚Äôve dealt with many Premiers on many many different issues all the time. I‚Äôve dealt with the Queensland Premier on other issues. ‚ÄúSadly today I didn‚Äôt have the influence that I would hope to have. But Sarah doesn‚Äôt get today back.‚Äù Ms Caisip told Channel Nine health authorities only got back to her saying she could attend last Friday. ‚ÄúThey only got back to me on Friday last week to tell me I was able to come to Queensland but it was two days after he had already passed away. A lot of people are helping and a lot of people are angry but you know.‚Äù Ms Caisip travelled to Queensland to spend time with her father during his final days but he died before she could get out of quarantine. Her father‚Äôs funeral was scheduled for 2pm but she was told in the hours leading up to the funeral that she could not attend. Up to 100 of her family and friends were allowed to attend the 2pm service in Mount Gravatt. Sarah Caisip could not see her dying father one last time because of COVID-19 border restrictions. Picture: Annette DewSource:News Corp Australia His funeral went ahead without her while she was forced to view his body alone. Picture: Annette DewSource:News Corp Australia Earlier Health Minister Greg Hunt urged the Queensland Premier to allow her to attend wearing a mask. ‚ÄúObviously I think the most sensible and sensitive and compassionate thing to do with regard to Sarah‚Äôs case is if in a COVID-safe way obviously masked and with any other appropriate distancing Sarah were able to attend the full funeral I think that would be the most humane compassionate thing to do‚Äô‚Äô he said. Ms Caisip wrote a heartbreaking letter to the Queensland Premier after she was unable to cross the border to spend time with him during his final days. ‚ÄúMy dad is dead and you made me fight to see him but it was too late and now you won‚Äôt let me go to his funeral or see my devastated 11-year-old sister‚Äù Ms Caisip said. ‚ÄúYou won‚Äôt listen and your government is destroying my life. RELATED: PM close to tears in intense interview Ms Caisip was desperate to leave hotel quarantine for a few hours to attend her father Bernard Prendergast‚Äôs funeral and to comfort her younger sister Isobel 11. Picture: News Regional MediaSource:Supplied ‚ÄúNow you are preventing me from going to view his body which is a very important tradition for me and also preventing me from going to his funeral this Thursday even though I am in Brisbane in hotel quarantine and only a few kilometres away. ‚ÄúI came from virus-free Canberra so the fact that I‚Äôm even in quarantine is beyond belief but the fact that I am being denied my basic human rights to care for my grief-stricken mother and little 11-year-old sister enrages disgusts and devastates me at the same time. ‚ÄúMy little sister is now without my support and I will never forgive you.‚Äù Just after noon Queensland chief health officer Jeanette Young said she would be let out of hotel quarantine for a private viewing of the body. The exemption to attend the funeral was not granted. RELATED: Premier accuses PM of ‚Äòbullying‚Äô her Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison was close to tears talking about the case on radio this morning. Picture: AAP Image/Lukas CochSource:AAP Earlier the Prime Minister confirmed this morning he had called Annastacia Palaszczuk and demanded she take action to allow the woman to skip quarantine so she can attend the funeral which is taking place this afternoon. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve appealed to her to overrule the decision‚Äô‚Äô Mr Morrison told 4BC radio. ‚ÄúThat would allow Sarah to go to the funeral today. It‚Äôs not about borders. It‚Äôs not about politicians. It‚Äôs not about elections. The only thing that matters today is that Sarah can be with her 11 year old sister Isobel and her mother while they mourn the passing of their husband Bernard.‚Äù Both Mr Morrison and radio broadcaster Ray Hadley were in on the verge of tears during the emotional interview as they discussed their own father‚Äôs deaths. ‚ÄúSadly she wasn‚Äôt able to see her father before he passed. All of us who have been through that process know how important that is. It‚Äôs still fresh in my mind‚Äô‚Äô he said. Mr Morrison continued on the verge of tears after pausing as he discussed her being in hotel quarantine on Father‚Äôs Day. ‚ÄúSurely just this once this can be done‚Äô‚Äô he said. ‚ÄúThere have been no COVID cases in Canberra for 60 days. I‚Äôve done all I can.‚Äù RELATED: ‚ÄòPrisoners‚Äô: Dutton hits out at border rules Sarah Caisip missed her father‚Äôs funeral because of the strict rules in place. Picture: SuppliedSource:Facebook But one Queensland Government source told news.com.au ‚ÄúHe wasn‚Äôt bloody crying when he rang the Premier and berated her‚Äô‚Äô he said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not her call. It‚Äôs the chief health officers. The PM rang and said ‚ÄúYou will do this. She had to remind him it was ‚ÄúR U OK? day.‚Äù In Parliament the Queensland Premier accused the Prime Minister of bullying her over borders. ‚ÄúI will not be bullied nor will I be intimidated by the Prime Minister‚Äô‚Äô she said.
