headline: Lily Allen married by Elvis in tiny Las Vegas wedding to Stranger Things star David Harbour
text: Allen‚Äôs wedding to actor David Harbour had face masks an unusual wedding dress an Elvis impersonator and a fast food reception. Stranger Things is a global sensation but is it something that actually happened? Elvis Presley impersonator and Las Vegas chapel co-owner Brendan Paul married Lily Allen and David Harbour. Picture: AFPSource:AFP Songstress Lily Allen has been married to her Stranger Things star partner by an Elvis impersonator in a small Las Vegas chapel. Allen 35 married David Harbour 45 at the celebrity-friendly Graceland Wedding Chapel using her previous married name Lily Cooper The Sun reports. Lily had been seen wearing a massive engagement ring in David‚Äôs home city of New York. The couple were married by Brendan Paul owner of the 30-seat Elvis-themed chapel and one of the most famous Elvis impersonators in Sin City. Allen and Harbour both shared several photos from the low-key nuptials on their Instagram accounts overnight: Lily Allen‚Äôs Las Vegas wedding. Picture: davidharbour/InstagramSource:Instagram The couple were married by an Elvis impersonator.Source:Instagram ‚ÄúIn a wedding officiated by the king himself the people‚Äôs princess wed her devoted low born but kind credit card holder in a beautiful ceremony lit by the ashen skies courtesy of a burning state miles away in the midst of a global pandemic. Refreshments were served at a small reception following‚Äù Harbour wrote on Instagram. Page Six reports Allen‚Äôs unusual wedding dress was ‚Äúa double-breasted Dior number with a bateau neckline black buttons belted waist and above-the-knee hemline paired with black suede platforms. A black version currently retails for $US4300 at Dior.  Allen wore a face mask for a fast food reception. Picture: davidharbour/InstagramSource:Instagram Lily‚Äôs first marriage ‚Äì to builder and decorator Sam Cooper ‚Äì was a very different affair. The pair married at St James‚Äô Church in Cranham Gloucester in the summer of 2011 with the pair welcoming their second child Marnie Rose later that year. Lily Allen and David Harbour just hitched.Source:Instagram Harbour rose to fame on Stranger Things as Jim Hopper and has also had roles on Brokeback Mountain Quantum of Solace and Hellboy. Guests at the chapel wedding had to wear face masks but the happy couple showed off their faces. There were four other weddings at the chapel on Monday when Lily tied the knot including one that was Hawaiian themed which featured a hula dancer and Brendan singing as Elvis. David and Lily first publicly revealed they were a couple on a night out to the theatre in London in August 2019 ‚Äì months after he split from previous girlfriend Alison Sudol. Stopping for a post-wedding bite to eat.Source:Instagram Allen‚Äôs daughters were also there to celebrate. Picture: davidharbour/InstagramSource:Instagram Allen later confirmed things were serious at the after-party for an edition of Saturday Night Live he had posted posting a shot of his bulging bicep writing: ‚ÄúMine.‚Äù The couple had recently enjoyed a trip to Croatia along with Allen‚Äôs two daughters: The Graceland Wedding Chapel Allen and Harbour chose for their nuptials has a long history of celebrity weddings. Stranger Things actor David Harbour. Picture: InstagramSource:Supplied Rocker Jon Bon Jovi married Dorothea in a late-night ceremony there using his real name John Bongiovi in 1989. The couple who are still together went on to have four kids. headline: China urges Twitter investigate foot fetish porn post liked by UK ambassador Liu Xiaoming‚Äôs account
text: China has called for a ‚Äúthorough investigation‚Äù after a social media account belonging to its ambassador liked a foot fetish film.  China has called for a thorough investigation after its ambassador to the UK's Twitter account liked a pornographic foot fetish video on the site.Source:Twitter The UK‚Äôs Chinese embassy has called on Twitter to investigate accusations that ‚Äúanti-China elements‚Äù hijacked ambassador Liu Xiaoming‚Äôs account to like pornographic videos and posts critical of China. A London-based human rights campaigner screenshotted and posted some of the content that had been liked by a Twitter account belonging to the ambassador on Wednesday night according to the BBC. One of them was a short and pornographic foot fetish video. RELATED: Controversy as Insta account sold for $116m A censored screenshot showing a foot fetish video liked by a Twitter account belonging to the Chinese ambassador to the UK.Source:Twitter RELATED: Osama bin Laden‚Äôs niece endorses Trump ‚ÄúThe CCP is stationed in the British Empire! We make it famous!‚Äù wrote the anti-communist account that posted a video showing Mr Liu‚Äôs account having liked the pornographic clip. ‚ÄúLucky quality single guy warm up first‚Äù read the caption on the video from an account which posts ‚Äúbeautiful legs in stockings‚Äù and ‚Äúb**ches from time to time‚Äù. Other posts allegedly liked by the ambassador‚Äôs account included ones heavily critical of China and its ruling communist party made by other users in response to the account‚Äôs posts. RELATED: ‚ÄòMisleading‚Äô: US TV network slammed A screenshot showing China's UK ambassador had liked an anti-China post.Source:Supplied China has always adhered to the principle of making lip service to non-interference in internal affairs so they can murder their own people without condemnation by the world. Free Hong Kong Free Manchuria Free Mongolia Free the Uighurs Free the Shan overthrow the Thai junta. RELATED: New tactic to hack your Facebook ‚ÄúChina has always adhered to the principle of making lip service to noninterference in internal affairs so they can murder their own people without condemnation by the world‚Äù a man describing himself as a ‚ÄúMAGA‚Äù follower ‚ÄúAsiaphile‚Äù and ‚Äúnemesis of social engineering in all its forms‚Äù said in response to one of Mr Liu‚Äôs tweets. China has now called on Twitter to conduct a ‚Äúthorough investigation‚Äù claiming Mr Liu‚Äôs account was ‚Äúviciously attacked‚Äù by ‚Äúanti-China elements‚Äù. ‚ÄúThe Embassy has reported this to Twitter company and urged the latter to make thorough investigations and handle this matter seriously‚Äù the embassy said in a statement. ‚ÄúThe Embassy reserves the right to take further actions and hope that the public will not believe or spread such rumour‚Äù the statement added. China has urged Twitter to investigate. Picture: Olivier Douliery/AFPSource:AFP Mr Liu‚Äôs account has been sterilised and now only lists two of his own posts as liked tweets. In the same way that RTs generally mean endorsements a liked tweet does not necessarily indicate agreeance. The feature is also used as a bookmarking tool to save tweets you want to revisit in the future. It‚Äôs also possible the likes were made by accident however China appears to be alleging it was a deliberate attack. Similar incidents have occurred in Australia. In 2017 the Twitter account of Health Minister Greg Hunt liked an explicit tweet from the account BBW C*M PUMPER 69 a month after then-Defence Minister Christopher Pyne appeared to like a tweet containing gay pornography. Mr Pyne accused someone of trying to make ‚Äúmischief over the plebiscite‚Äù as Australia prepared to eventually vote that gay people should be allowed to get married. At the time a spokesman for Mr Hunt told news.com.au his account had been hacked and the matter had been referred to the AFP whose investigation later found that was not true. ‚ÄúThe account was not hacked in a criminal sense‚Äù AFP commissioner Andrew Colvin told a Senate estimates hearing a few months later. Mr Colvin added the incident was ‚Äúabout who has access to your Twitter account how many people have access‚Äù. ‚ÄúI think social media hygiene is an issue that we all need to be very conscious of‚Äù Mr Colvin said. headline: Sunrise star Sam Mac explains why he‚Äôs been wearing a wristband on TV for 12 months
text: Every couple of days Sunrise star Sam Mac gets asked the same question: ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs that on your wrist?‚Äù Now he‚Äôs revealed what it is. Eight Australians a day take their own lives but suicide is preventable. How can you help? Sam Mac wearing his R U OK? wristband.Source:Supplied Every couple of days Sunrise weatherman Sam Mac gets asked the same question: ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs that on your wrist?‚Äù For 12 whole months the Channel 7 star has been sporting a yellow wristband during his TV crosses and now he‚Äôs revealed to news.com.au what it‚Äôs all about. ‚ÄúLast year on R U OK? we were covering it on Sunrise and I wore my yellow wristband which has the R U OK? website written on it‚Äù Sam said. Sam Mac‚Äôs wristband can be seen in this shot from Sunrise.Source:Channel 7 ‚ÄúInitially it was more of a reminder to myself to be more in tune with mental health conversations and to remind myself that you never really know what someone is going through. Just seeing that wristband in the corner of my eye keeps me in check with that and keeps me alert to chatting to people about those kinds of topics.‚Äù But the wristband has had a bigger flow-on benefit Sam told news.com.au. ‚ÄúSo many people watch our show and every couple of days someone will write to me on social media or ask me face-to-face ‚ÄòWhat is that yellow wristband?‚Äô‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúSome people knew it was R U OK? so it was a bit of an ice breaker and they felt comfortable to have a chat about mental health with me ‚Ä¶ and some people thought it was the Lance Armstrong Livestrong wristband which it‚Äôs absolutely not‚Äù Sam laughed. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs such a tiny thing but it‚Äôs meant a lot.‚Äù Sam Mac sporting his wristband in Canada.Source:Instagram Sam Mac with his R U OK? wristband.Source:Supplied R U OK? day is a cause close to Sam‚Äôs heart after the death of radio star Richard Marsland in 2008. ‚ÄúI lost a friend to his battle with mental health over a decade ago. I remember so clearly the feeling when I got the call about Richard. It‚Äôs such a sharp vivid memory and almost instantly I remember wanting to do something to help in that space‚Äù Sam said. ‚ÄúI got involved with R U OK? and my mission is pretty simple ‚Äì to make people understand that there is support and that talking about it is a healthy thing.‚Äù Today is R U OK? Day. Use these four steps and have a conversation that could change a life: 1. Ask R U OK? 2. Listen 3. Encourage action 4. Check in You can check out more info on the R U OK website. headline: 4.5-metre crocodile spotted speeding up Far North Qld river
text: A fisherman has captured the moment a massive crocodile raced past his dinghy before coming ‚Äútoo close for comfort‚Äù.  A huge croc has been filmed porpoising like a dolphin on a Far North Queensland river in what experts describe as 'unusual' and 'very scary' behaviour. Tommy the Tank speeding up the Bloomfield River. Picture: Robert DunnSource:Supplied A far north Qld fisherman has captured terrifying footage of a huge saltwater crocodile tearing through the water next to his boat as another saltie in the NT reminds us what the prehistoric beasts are capable of. Commercial fisherman Robert Dunn captured footage of the croc estimated to be about 4.5-metres speeding along the Bloomfield River north of Cairns on Monday diving under and resurfacing repeatedly as it races up the river. Tommy the Tank speeding up the Bloomfield River. Picture: Robert DunnSource:Supplied RELATED: Horror attack captured on swell camera RELATED: Elephant to be freed after 35 years He told the  Cairns Post the crocodile was bigger than the boat he was in. ‚ÄúI was only in a 3.5-metre tinny and he cruised right next to me‚Äù Mr Dunn said. Mr Dunn said the crocodile was well known because ‚Äúhe keeps eating all the dogs‚Äù in the area near the Wujal Wujal Aboriginal community and had even been given the name Tommy the Tank by locals. ‚ÄúHe came up with this growl and locked eyes with me‚Äù Mr Dunn said telling the Post he feared Tommy might be sizing up his dinghy as he swam underneath it. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve had a couple close calls before but that was a bloody game changer‚Äù he told the Today show on Thursday morning. ‚ÄúIt was close came a bit too close for comfort.‚Äù RELATED: Whale seen with new baby after tragedy Tommy is estimated to be about 4.5 metres but there‚Äôs reportedly an even bigger croc in the surrounding waters. Picture: Robert DunnSource:Supplied RELATED: ‚ÄòTerror croc‚Äô that ate dinosaurs RELATED: Kangaroos have huge fight in the snow Mr Dunn added there was an even bigger croc in the area named Max who was the dominant male but more shy than Tommy. Daintree River croc guide David White told the Post it was ‚Äúvery unusual‚Äù and ‚Äúvery dangerous‚Äù behaviour from the croc. ‚ÄúI have seen a big male make a huge wake like that and swim high after another male but not as fast as this‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúPerhaps there was another male around or else just full of testosterone and angry. I certainly wouldn‚Äôt have been so calm.‚Äù He said crocodiles had been detected swimming at speeds up to 29km/h for short periods of time. The video came as another crocodile in the Northern Territory recently showed exactly what they can do. RELATED: Epic snake fight captured on camera Michele Bain snapped some great photos of crocs doing what they do best ‚Äì chewing into meat while out on Corroboree Billabong recently. Picture: Michele BainSource:Supplied The dominant croc fought off competitors for the fresh meat. Picture: Michele BainSource:Supplied  Photographer Michele Bain was at the Corroboree Billabong southeast of Darwin last Wednesday when she spotted a four metre crocodile taking down a cow. The saltie fought off other crocodiles who wanted some beef of their own. ‚ÄúWe saw so many crocs it was incredible‚Äù Ms Bain told the  NT News. ‚ÄúThere was a lot of splashing as they were all trying to have a piece but the big one wasn‚Äôt letting them have it.‚Äù She said the cow had all but disappeared when she and her husband returned the next day theorising the crocs had dragged it into the water. Michele Bain said the cow was mostly gone by the next day. headline: California fires: Satellite photos show blaze has covered western USA
text: Satellite images have shown thousands of wildfires burning across the United States as a Californian city is blanketed in an apocalyptic orange haze. San Francisco has a deep orange-tinted sky in the morning from a thick fog of smoke caused by the outbreak of wildfires across Northern California following historically high temperatures and strong winds. The San Francisco skyline is obscured in orange smoke and haze as fires rage in multiple states across the US. Picture: Brittany Hosea-Small/AFPSource:AFP Satellite images have shown the United States covered in thousands of wildfires burning across multiple states as a Californian city is blanketed in an apocalyptic orange haze. Wildfires are affecting numerous states across the US with out-of-control wildfires wreaking havoc in California for weeks. Western states including Washington Oregon and Colorado are struggling to contain fires in worsening conditions. Photos showing eerie scenes particularly of a San Francisco skyline fit for a dystopian science fiction film spread quickly on social media. ‚ÄúWe know the smoke darkness and orange glow is scary. Stay calm and try to stay indoors; it‚Äôs going to get better‚Äù the local fire department tweeted. RELATED: Fires plunge California into darkness A map shows hot spots detected through infra-red (orange) and satellite sensors (red) across the Unites States. Picture: Mappingsupport.comSource:Supplied This map from the Fire Weather and Avalanche Centre reports more than 2400 fires currently burning.Source:Supplied The San Francisco skyline is obscured in an unsettling orange smoke and haze. Picture: Brittany Hosea-Small/AFPSource:AFP A number of wildfires are burning in California and other states across the US. Picture: Philip Pacheco/Getty Images/AFPSource:AFP A man works out under the apocalyptic orange sky in San Francisco. Picture: Brittany Hosea-Small/AFPSource:AFP RELATED: Rain eases bushfire threat west of Melbourne In the small town of Malden in Washington officials said 80 per cent of structures have been destroyed by fires. The town of 200 has reportedly lost many essential buildings including its own fire station post office library and the city hall. The Sheriff Brett J Myers of Whitman county said fires had left the town looking like a ‚Äúkind of moonscape‚Äù. Drone video shows the complete devastation in the town of Malden.LATEST INFO: https://t.co/u8n2zogKab pic.twitter.com/dS5IblOBqZ Fires have also forced mandatory evacuations in Oregon with parts of the city of Medford evacuated on Tuesday night local time. At least five towns were ‚Äúsubstantially destroyed‚Äù in the state governor Kate Brown said citing early reports. ‚ÄúI want to be upfront in saying that we expect to see a great deal of loss both in structures and in human lives‚Äù she told a press conference. ‚ÄúThis could be the greatest loss of human lives and property due to wildfire in our state‚Äôs history.‚Äù Jody Evans a resident of Detroit ‚Äî one of the five towns razed in Oregon ‚Äî fled her home as the fire approached. ‚ÄúComing through fire on both sides trees down wind blowing ash flying‚Äù Ms Evans told Newschannel 21. ‚ÄúIt was like driving through hell.‚Äù On Monday the Governor of Washington Jay Inslee estimated 330000 acres had burned in his state. In California area burned is at 2.3 million acres up from 118000 acres last year. According to a map from the Fire Weather and Avalanche Centre there are currently 2416 active fires burning across the United States. A satellite photo shows smoke plumes from the west coast of the US on Wednesday. Picture: Agustin Paullier/RAMMB/NOAA/NESDIS/AFPSource:AFP An officer watches the fire in Oroville California on Wednesday. Picture: Josh Edelson/AFPSource:AFP In California at least eight deaths have been reported. In Oregon no deaths have been reported yet but officials warned they believed fatalities were likely saying they hadn‚Äôt been able to access some of the hardest hit areas. headline: Tassie devil relative the mulgara reintroduced into NSW a century after extinction
text: A tiny carnivorous marsupial has been reintroduced to NSW after being declared extinct in the state more than a century ago. An Asian elephant ‚Äúhit the spa‚Äù recently enjoying a mud bath at Oregon Zoo footage shared on September 3 shows The video posted to the zoo‚Äôs Facebook account captured elephant Samudra splashing about and rolling around in the refreshing pool of mud. Credit: Oregon Zoo via Storyful A small carnivorous marsupial related to the Tasmanian devil has been reintroduced to a NSW national park. Picture: Handout via NCA NewsWireSource:NCA NewsWire They may be small but the mulgara is mighty. The tiny carnivorous marsupial which is related to the Tasmanian devil was declared extinct in NSW more than a century ago. But thanks to local scientists the mysterious crest-tailed mulgara has been reintroduced to the state and will make Sturt National Park its new home. The team behind the initiative which is led by UNSW‚Äôs Wild Deserts project is hoping to establish a self-sustaining population in the depths of the state‚Äôs northwest away from the prying eyes of cats rabbits and foxes. The mulgara was declared extinct in NSW more than a century ago. Picture: Handout via NCA NewsWireSource:NCA NewsWire Two exclosures spanning across 2000 hectares each have been established at the park. Nineteen mulgaras will be rehomed in the southern exclosure Mingku which means ‚Äúhappy‚Äù in Maljangapa language. While tiny shy animals mulgaras are described as ‚Äúferocious predators‚Äù and share similarities with their Tasmanian devil cousins. They feast on reptiles insects and other small mammals. Wild Deserts leader UNSW professor Richard Kingsford said the population of crest-tailed mulgara was restricted to a relatively small area mainly within the Strzelecki and Simpson deserts in South Australia. Mulgaras are fierce predators.Source:Supplied He said the species was once widely distributed across sandy desert environments in inland Australia but introduced pests including rabbits cats and foxes have contributed to their decline. In 2017 scientists made the shock discovery of a solitary mulgara living within the Wild Deserts site. Before this the animal was presumed extinct in NSW for more than 100 years. ‚ÄúThey are still listed as extinct in NSW under the Biodiversity Conservation Act‚Äù Prof Kingsford said. Tiny footprints left behind by the desert predator. Picture: Handout via NCA NewsWireSource:NCA NewsWire Academics decided to reintroduce the species after they had no luck finding evidence of a population in the area. Recent rainfall has helped boost vegetation in the park meaning there are now more small mammals and insects for the mulgara to prey on. ‚ÄúThe rain has been fabulous really kickstarting the ecosystem after prolonged drought and creating ideal conditions for these reintroductions‚Äù Dr Reece Pedler co-ordinator of the Wild Deserts project said. ‚ÄúWe currently know little about crest-tailed mulgara biology and breeding in the wild so the project will contribute to both species knowledge and recovery.‚Äù A team of scientists are hoping to establish a self-sustaining population. Picture: Handout via NCA NewsWireSource:NCA NewsWire As a micro-predator the mulgara plays a critical ecological role. The mulgara release is the first of seven mammal species to be reintroduced to the Wild Deserts site as part of the NSW Government‚Äôs wider Saving our Species program. Future species releases will include greater bilby burrowing bettong western quoll and western barred bandicoot. headline: Myer: Solomon Lew‚Äôs Premier Investments slams ‚Äúdesperate shameful‚Äù department store
text: Myer has been slammed by its biggest investor which said it seems determined to become the ‚Äúworld‚Äôs most expensive post office‚Äù. Myer has fallen into loss due to the pandemic. Picture: AAP Image/Joe Castro.Source:AAP Myer‚Äôs biggest shareholder has lashed out at the department store calling its slump into loss ‚Äúdisastrous and shameful‚Äù the company ‚Äúdesperate‚Äù and demanding the entire board resign. Premier Investments which owns retailers Just Jeans Smiggle and Peter Alexander said Myer‚Äôs only turnaround plan appeared to be a hook up with online retailer Amazon that would turn it into ‚Äúthe world‚Äôs most expensive post office‚Äù. Premier whose chairman is outspoken retailer Solomon Lew holds almost 11 per cent of Myer stock making it the single biggest shareholder. However Premier itself has come under fire after it said last month it expected to post a record profit of potentially up to $185 million while it has also taken advantage of the Federal Government‚Äôs JobKeeper program to subsidise wages. According to some reports Premier may have claimed tens of millions of taxpayer dollars. The firm also refused to pay rent on many of its stores during the height of the pandemic. RELATED: Move by insurers an ‚Äòominous‚Äô sign of Myer financial health Myer has fallen into loss due to the pandemic. Picture: AAP Image/Joe Castro.Source:AAP ‚ÄòWORLD‚ÄôS MOST EXPENSIVE POST OFFICE‚Äô On Thursday Myer said it had lost $172.4 million in the last financial year a steep drop from 2019‚Äôs $24.5 million profit. It said sales fell almost 16 per cent to $2.5 billion for the financial year after widespread store closures during the nationwide lockdown. Online sales grew 99 per cent in the second half of financial year compared to the prior year. The significant increase in online sales made up 17 per cent of total sales for the department store. The growth in online sales was bolstered by agreements with Australia Post and Amazon. Myer recently introduced Amazon Hub ‚Äì Amazon parcel pick-up points at Myer Click & Collect counters ‚Äì in 21 stores. A deal with Australia Post has also helped to deliver products to customers. ‚ÄúThese new warehouse and fulfilment arrangements will underpin the next stage of growth in Myer‚Äôs online business delivering benefits to Myer‚Äôs customers as well as providing significant cost savings‚Äù CEO John King said. However Premier laid into the Amazon deal as an example of where Myer was ‚Äúlost‚Äù. ‚ÄúMyer appears to be transforming itself into the world‚Äôs most expensive post office. Its latest deal hinges on the hope Amazon customers buy something else on whim when they collect product from the Myer badged post office. It is desperate and sums up just how lost Myer is‚Äù the statement said. RELATED: Kmart boss hits out at Melbourne restrictions Premier Investment‚Äôs Soloman Lew took aim at Myer and its management. Picture: Aaron Francis/The AustralianSource:News Corp Australia Premier called for the ‚Äúimmediate resignation of the Myer board‚Äù and for an ‚Äúurgent‚Äù management overhaul. ‚ÄúToday‚Äôs results are disastrous and shameful. Two years into John King‚Äôs tenure ‚Äì it‚Äôs clear the Myer turnaround is in tatters. ‚ÄúAs a long-suffering investor and supplier Premier itself is perplexed. ‚ÄúThe numbers are dire ‚Äì notwithstanding the impact of COVID-19 the business is trading beyond poorly‚Äù it added. Premier own stationery shop Smiggle. Picture: Peter Wallis.Source:News Limited ‚ÄúIn exchange for delivering today‚Äôs statutory net loss after tax of $172.4 million ‚Äì the second biggest loss in Myer‚Äôs history Chairman Gary Hounsell has been paid $246000 while John King pocketed $1.59 million‚Äù the statement said. ‚ÄúYet again Myer shareholders have been taken for a ride.‚Äù Myer CEO John King. Picture: Stefan Postles.Source:News Corp Australia LONG HISTORY BETWEEN PREMIER AND MYER Premier has a long history of attacking Myer and there is no love lost between the two retailers. Despite Mr Lew‚Äôs Premier holding one in ten Myer shares the department store has fended off attempts by the company to have representation on the board. At the results announcement Myer‚Äôs Mr King said shutting all 60 stores in April and May cutting wages and standing down approximately 10000 team members was a hard decision. ‚ÄúClosing the stores is one of the toughest decisions faced in our history‚Äù Mr King said. Ongoing restrictions in Melbourne are still affecting store closures. The retailer received $93 million in JobKeeper payments while $41 million was paid to employees whose remuneration was lower than the required income threshold. Wages fell by $73 million as the firm stood down staff. As more people are stuck at home Myer has seen changed behaviour in its customers with items such as cooking appliances casualwear and athleisure becoming more popular. ‚ÄúMyer looks ahead to a permanently-changed CBD landscape with workers working from home‚Äù Mr King commented. - with Kathy Skantzos. headline: Australia Post Pauline Hanson in ‚Äòhate mail‚Äô scandal
text: Australia Post has become engulfed in a scandal involving Pauline Hanson stubby holders and residents in a locked-down public housing tower. Australia Post has asked workers to ‚Äúvolunteer‚Äù to deliver parcels because of a surge in online shopping. Australia Post Group chief executive officer Christine Holgate has been accused of pushing for 114 parcels containing One Nation stubby holders be delivered to residents at a housing commission tower. Picture: Gary RamageSource:News Corp Australia Australia Post has become engulfed in scandal over its push for Pauline Hanson‚Äôs One Nation-branded stubby holders to be delivered to residents in a locked-down Melbourne public housing tower. Explosive allegations published in The Age claim Australian Post boss Christine Holgate threatened to call police unless the City of Melbourne ‚Äì which was managing the government-enforced lockdown of the public housing towers ‚Äì delivered 114 parcels containing the stubby holders. The council had intercepted the parcels at a complex in July. Australia Post‚Äôs intervention came as it sought Senate approval to ease its obligation to deliver mail from Monday to Friday to every second business day in metropolitan areas until June next year. Federal MPs are demanding Ms Holgate explain her actions which followed Senator Hanson being banned from the Today show for making racist comments about residents in the housing commission towers. It‚Äôs believed council officials decided against delivering the stubby holders out of fears they would inflame an already tense situation. Victorian Labor MP and multicultural affairs spokesman Andrew Giles said Australia Post helped Senator Hanson add insult to injury to those Australians who did not want the items. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs hard to imagine a bigger prompt to annoy people than a stubby holder (from Senator Hanson) saying ‚ÄòI‚Äôm thinking what you‚Äôre thinking‚Äô‚Äù he said. One Nation leader Senator Pauline Hanson was accused of making ‚Äòill-informed and divisive‚Äô comments after she suggested that residents locked down in Melbourne‚Äôs housing commissions couldn‚Äôt speak English. Picture: Gary RamageSource:News Corp Australia Senator Hanson‚Äôs stubby holder. Picture: SuppliedSource:NCA NewsWire It's caused a stir for Australian Post CEO Christine Holgate. Picture: SuppliedSource:Supplied Mr Giles said the events raised questions about Ms Holgate‚Äôs leadership and the priorities of Australia Post under that leadership. ‚ÄúThe CEO from the reports had a very direct involvement‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThe reports make clear that Australians deserve to get to the bottom of why it was that the CEO of Australia Post was working so hard to appease a crossbench senator. ‚ÄúIn circumstances where the police were called it appears to make sure that Pauline Hanson‚Äôs hate mail gets delivered to public housing tenants while not only is Australia Post unable to confirm timely delivery of essential items. This raises really big questions.‚Äù Independent Senator Rex Patrick said it was proper for Australia Post to deliver mail and parcels in a reliable and timely manner. ‚ÄúBut how many times has Australia Post‚Äôs general counsel written threatening to call in the police to ensure good service? I suspect not often‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThis requires further investigation. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll be making a freedom of information request today to see how many similar letters have been penned by general counsel recently.‚Äù Many people are asking where they can find one of the famous Pauline Hanson stubby coolers.You can find them at the @OneNationAus shop onlineLINK: https://t.co/1ShWCFlBELMight as well get your Christmas shopping done early and help out One Nation at the same time! pic.twitter.com/rqK0PdMVCM An Australia Post spokesman told The Age it took its obligation to deliver mail ‚Äúseriously‚Äù. ‚ÄúUpon subsequently being made aware that the items did not reach their ultimate destination we raised it with the City of Melbourne and engaged with the sender in good faith to resolve the matter‚Äù the spokesman said. Australian Greens communications spokeswoman Sarah Hanson-Young who has a meeting scheduled with Ms Holgate on Monday said she would ask about her involvement. ‚ÄúI have a long list of things to talk to the CEO about‚Äù Senator Hanson-Young said.  ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs also an issue which will get some attention during Senate Estimates.‚Äù She condemned Senator Hanson‚Äôs move to deliver the stubby holders to the flats ‚Äúappalling behaviour‚Äù for an elected member of parliament. Senator Hanson‚Äôs office was contacted for comment. headline: Single-use plastics banned in South Australia: Queensland could be next
text: South Australia has beaten Queensland as the first state to ban plastic straws cutlery and drink stirrers but COVID is delaying when it can come into effect.  We look at the widespread effect single-use and large form plastics have on our environment. South Australia has passed legislation banning single-use plastics.Source:istock South Australia has become the first state in the country to ban single-use plastics with parliament passing the legislation yesterday.  The new ban won‚Äôt come into effect until 2021 though due to delays caused by the pandemic. The state has beaten Queensland to the punch which has been debating new laws with new legislation on the agenda for its state parliament this month. The new rules in South Australia puts a stop to the sale supply and distribution of plastic straws cutlery and drink stirrers ‚Äì and may include other plastic items such as coffee cups and fruit and vegetable carrier bags later on. South Australia has become the first state to ban single-use plastics in Australia. Picture: Joel Carrett/AAPSource:AAP RELATED: Ban on plastic straws a step closer South Australian Environment and Water Minister David Speirs said there has been strong feedback from South Australians keen to see action on single-use plastics. ‚ÄúThere has been significant community and industry support for swift action on single-use plastic products with many households and businesses across the state already taking steps to remove them‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWith COVID-19 restrictions still impacting on society and in particular the hospitality industry we will delay the commencement of the legislation‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThis will give businesses time to bounce back and properly prepare before the ban comes into effect in early 2021. This approach strikes an appropriate balance between the public‚Äôs desire for change and the needs of businesses.‚Äù He described the approach as a balance to benefit the environment while minimising the impact for businesses and accommodating the needs of people living with a disability who might find themselves reliant on certain single-use plastics. Banning plastic items will take a staged approach with the aim to remove them altogether. Mr Speirs described the state as ‚Äúa leader in waste management‚Äù as it was the first state or territory to ban plastic bags in 2009. ‚ÄúWe were the first state in Australia to introduce deposits on containers the first state in Australia to ban lightweight plastic bags and we‚Äôre now the first state to pass legislation banning single-use plastics‚Äù he said. The proposal for Queensland to change its laws comes after the State Government asked Queenslanders what to do about single-use plastics in an inquiry and received almost 20000 submissions since November 2019 begging for a ban. headline: Brisbane Broncos monster settlement to Anthony Seibold revealed
text: Coach Anthony Seibold has gone to hell and back in 2020 but a reported monster payout means he has a small fortune to show for it. NRL: Rabbitohs coach Wayne Bennett has denied reports he is considering a move back to the Broncos but Peter Badel believes it could still be on the cards. Anthony Seibold at RedHill.Source:News Corp Australia Forced out Broncos coach Anthony Seibold has reportedly pocketed $1.5 million in a monster payout from the Brisbane Broncos.  The 45-year-old last month announced his decision to walk away with three seasons remaining on his long-term deal with the Broncos. Reports claimed in August Seibold stood to earn up to $3.2 million to see out his full contract at the club with contrasting reports claiming the mentor also had a sixth-year option to extend his tenure through to the end of 2024. Kayo is your ticket to the 2020 NRL Telstra Premiership. Every game of every round Live & On-Demand with no-ad breaks during play. New to Kayo? Get your 14-day free trial & start streaming instantly > Seibold announced last month he would not be returning to the club to fight for his job after leaving the club‚Äôs biosecurity bubble to attend a private family matter. He instead negotiated a severance package to walk the plank just days after it was first reported the Broncos had made him an offer of $1 million to walk away without seeing out the end of the 2020 season. The club previously claimed Seibold would be given until the end of 2020 before his position was to be reviewed. When it became clear Seibold would not survive the review he and the club both dug in to thrash out a settlement. Anthony Seibold at Red Hill.Source:News Corp Australia Fox League reporter James Hooper revealed Seibold dug his heels in during the negotiations reportedly holding out for $2 million. ‚ÄúI think he‚Äôs digging his heels in and his advisers are attempting to extrapolate as much money as possible out of that Broncos contract‚Äù Hooper said more than two weeks ago. ‚ÄúNow the initial figure the Broncos have pushed across the negotiating table to part company is a tick over a million dollars. I think Seibold‚Äôs advisors and Anthony Seibold will push for more like $2 million and we‚Äôll have to see this now thrashed out over the course of the next couple of days. I think in all likelihood he has coached his last game in charge of the Brisbane Broncos.‚Äù The Courier-Mail on Thursday revealed Seibold‚Äôs payout finished up at $1.5 million. Despite his turbulent tenure Seibold and the club are reported to have ended their relationship on good terms with the coach speaking to reporters for hours on the day he announced his decision to walk away before he was sacked. Anthony Seibold is a free agent.Source:News Corp Australia The Broncos have had the worst season in the club‚Äôs history with just three wins in 17 games sitting ahead of only the Canterbury Bulldogs. They have the worst defence and the second worst attack in the league. Seibold has been under relentless pressure in the role with the dire performances putting the coach under the spotlight after each loss. But along with the rumours around Seibold that have been sent to lawyers the Broncos have also been dealing with infighting with former greats lashing the once powerhouse club and star forward Tevita Pangai Jr in a media storm after numerous COVID bubble breaches. The club have also had a sex tape scandal and been under biosecurity investigations for a pub lunch attended by several players. Assistant coach Peter Gentle is coaching the Broncos for the rest of the season as the club continues its search for the right man to eventually replace Seibold as head coach. headline: Nick Nurse‚Äôs questionable tactics raise eyebrows as Raptors down Celtics
text: An NBA star has hit out at an opposing coach for his end of game tactics that kept his team‚Äôs hopes of securing back-to-back championships. NBA: The Toronto Raptors and Boston Celtics put on an absolute show in Game 6 of their series with the match going into double overtime as both teams hit big shots. Nick Nurse standing on the courtSource:Supplied Kyle Lowry scored 33 points and Norman Powell added 23 off the bench as defending champion Toronto bagged a series-levelling 125-122 double overtime victory over Boston in the NBA playoffs. An emotional thriller that resembled the intensity of a heavyweight boxing match-up saw the Raptors sustain their repeat hopes and pull level 3-3 in the Eastern Conference semi-finals with a winner-take-all game seven set for Saturday. Watch the best of the NBA Playoffs including every game of the Conference Finals and Finals LIVE on ESPN with Kayo. New to Kayo? Get your free trial now & start streaming instantly > The winner advances to an Eastern Conference final showdown against Miami. ‚ÄúJust winning‚Äù an exhausted Lowry said after playing 53 minutes. ‚ÄúThat was two hard teams playing hard. We had to win the game. Win or go home. ‚ÄúGet it done. Don‚Äôt matter who has to do it. Ready for game seven.‚Äù Powell made a steal and fast break lay-up plus a free throw to lift Toronto ahead 121-117 with 38 seconds remaining. Jayson Tatum answered with an inside jumper but Lowry hit a fall-away jumper ‚Äî Toronto‚Äôs sixth successful shot in a row ‚Äî to put Toronto ahead 123-119. Tatum sank a 3-pointer to pull Boston within a point with 6.2 seconds remaining but Powell sank two free throws and Marcus Smart missed a last-chance 3-pointer for Boston. Tatum was also responsible for a crucial turnover late in the fourth quarter when he thought he was passing to a teammate ‚Äî only to mistake Raptors coach Nick Nurse on the sideline for a fellow Celtic. ‚ÄúI mean I turned it over‚Äù Tatum said reluctant to shift the blame. ‚ÄúThat was my fault. Can‚Äôt blame Nick Nurse. He‚Äôs not playing. It was my fault.‚Äù But Boston star Jaylen Brown wasn‚Äôt as forgiving saying Nurse should have controlled himself. ‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs a lot of emotions‚Äù Brown said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs very intense and things like that and sometimes things seem to go overboard at times. Let‚Äôs keep it in check let‚Äôs keep it respectable and let‚Äôs keep playing basketball. ‚ÄúGrown men should be able to control themselves especially coaching staff. So let‚Äôs continue to do what we gotta do play basketball and be ready to fight.‚Äù RELATED: $347m decision hanging over star‚Äôs head RELATED: Single tweet shocks basketball world Interesting move here from Nick Nurse: pic.twitter.com/F0b3heqvKw Jaylen Brown scored 31 points and grabbed 16 rebounds to lead Boston while Tatum had 29 points 14 rebounds and nine assists and Smart managed only his second carer triple-double with 23 points 11 rebounds and 10 assists. ‚ÄúIt was a hard-played tough game. Could have gone either way‚Äù said Celtics coach Brad Stevens. ‚ÄúGreat basketball game. Right now put some ice on your legs and get ready for Saturday.‚Äù The Raptors won their first NBA crown last season but NBA Finals Most Valuable Player Kawhi Leonard left in the off-season for the Los Angeles Clippers. Fred VanVleet added 21 points for Toronto and German centre Daniel Theis had 18 points for Boston. A Theis dunk lifted the Celtics level at 98-98 with two minutes remaining in regulation time. Toronto‚Äôs Pascal Siakam and Boston‚Äôs Kemba Walker each missed inside shots in the dying seconds and Siakam missed a desperation 3-point heave at the buzzer setting up overtime. Walker hit a jumper to give the Celtics a 104-101 lead but Norman Powell sank a left corner 3-pointer to tie the game then made two free throws with 92 seconds remaining in overtime to give Toronto a 106-104 edge. Tatum sank two free throws to tie the game with 18.9 seconds remaining in overtime and Powell missed a final 3-pointer to force double overtime. The Raptors forced a Game 7.Source:AFP Celtics trainers were working with injured playmaker Gordon Hayward who has re-completed quarantine in the COVID-19 bubble at Disney World in Orlando Florida but remains out indefinitely with a right ankle sprain. In a later game the Denver Nuggets faced the Los Angeles Clippers in a Western Conference semi-final with the Clippers leading the series 2-1. headline: Myer‚Äôs sales drop store closures offset by online
text: The pandemic proved a difficult time for Myer when it closed all 60 stories. But the retail giant has had a huge rise in one area. Before you buy another thing check out these tips to save you thousands online. More customers are turning to online.Source:AAP Myer‚Äôs total sales dropped almost 16 per cent to $2.5 billion for the financial year after widespread store closures resulting from the pandemic. This year‚Äôs results show a net loss of $172.4 million for the financial year compared to the net profit of $24.5 million in the previous financial year. However the department store‚Äôs online sales have increased by 61 per cent as shoppers change their buying behaviour. Online sales grew 99 per cent in the second half of financial year 2020 compared to the prior year. The significant increase in online sales made up 17 per cent of total sales for the department store. The growth in online sales was bolstered by agreements with Australia Post and Amazon announced last month. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve seen significant growth in our online business since COVID-19‚Äù Myer CEO John King said. ‚ÄúThere was particularly strong growth in beauty up 218 per cent and homewares up 177 per cent.‚Äù Myer‚Äôs recent introduction of Amazon Hub ‚Äì Amazon parcel pick-up points at Myer Click & Collect counters ‚Äì were introduced in 21 Myer stores across Australia yesterday. The deal with Australia Post has also helped to deliver products to customers. ‚ÄúThese new warehouse and fulfilment arrangements will underpin the next stage of growth in Myer‚Äôs online business to further strengthen the fulfilment capacity and improve efficiency delivering benefits to Myer‚Äôs customers as well as providing significant cost savings‚Äù Mr King said. The department store saw reduced traffic to stores mainly in the CBD areas as more people started working from home. As Myer closed all 60 stores in April and May it cut wages and stood down approximately 10000 team members. ‚ÄúClosing the stores is one of the toughest decisions faced in our history‚Äù Mr King said adding that a key focus has been on safety. Ongoing restrictions in Melbourne are still affecting store closures. ‚ÄúAs restrictions ease we will focus on providing safety to customers‚Äù Mr King said. ‚ÄúWhen the COVID-19 pandemic first hit we acted to prioritise the health and wellbeing of our customers team members and the broader communities in which we operate‚Äù he commented Myer relied heavily on government support to keep paying wages as it saw its profits drop and cash flow fall by $31 million. The retailer received $93 million in JobKeeper payments while $41 million was paid to employees whose remuneration was lower than the required income threshold. ‚ÄúWages fell by $73 million as we stood down many staff‚Äù Myer CFO Mr Chadwick said adding that the department store saved around $29 million due to staff costs and pay reductions as well as cuts to marketing and travel. As more people are stuck at home Myer has seen changed behaviour in its customers with items such as cooking appliances casualwear and athleisure becoming more popular. ‚ÄúMyer looks ahead to a permanently-changed CBD landscape with workers working from home‚Äù Mr King commented. Myer also plans to lower the threshold of its Myer One program in the hope to see more customers join the program. Mr King commented that the department giant has plans to grow the business to $1 billion over the coming years. ‚ÄúWe have aspirations for this to be a billion-dollar business‚Äù he said. The department store has extended it debt facility which is worth $340 million for two years. headline: AFL image of Jeremy Cameron is all wrong
text: Footy icons couldn‚Äôt believe their eyes as an alarming scene before Adelaide‚Äôs shock win over GWS sparked plenty of discussion.  AFL: David King asks why GWS is playing its highly-paid forward star Jeremy Cameron on the wing at the moment on Fox Footy. What was Jeremy Cameron doing here?Source:FOX SPORTS A demoralising loss to last-placed Adelaide on Tuesday night leaves GWS teetering on the brink of the top eight and AFL pundits are questioning if the Sydney club has lost its way. The Giants have been a finals lock in recent years without capturing an elusive premiership but they‚Äôre in danger of planning an early Mad Monday if they can‚Äôt sort themselves out in the final two rounds of the regular season. Kayo is your ticket to the 2020 Toyota AFL Premiership Season. Watch every match of every round Live & On-Demand. New to Kayo? Get your 14-day free trial & start streaming instantly > One of the troubling scenes from a 12-point defeat to the Crows was the sight of key forward Jeremy Cameron ‚Äî the AFL‚Äôs highest paid player on a salary reportedly worth more than $1.4 million ‚Äî lining up on the wing for the opening bounce of the match. The left-footer is a foundation player at the Giants and has been the team‚Äôs leading goalkicker every season since it entered the AFL. But rather than starting the biggest goal threat inside forward 50 against Adelaide Cameron was shunted to the wing ‚Äî a decision ex-Richmond and Western Bulldogs star Nathan Brown couldn‚Äôt understand. ‚ÄúThe other thing that confused me the other night was the first bounce‚Äù Brown said on Channel 9‚Äôs Footy Classified. ‚ÄúJeremy Cameron ‚Ä¶ he‚Äôs dropped off this year starting on the wing at the first bounce. ‚ÄúThis is something that you might try halfway through the second quarter halfway through the third quarter late in the game to get him into the game. ‚ÄúBut at the first bounce your weapon your No. 1 player you want forward of the ball to be marking the football probably their best kick inside forward 50 starting on the wing? ‚ÄúI just didn‚Äôt get this from (Giants coach) Leon Cameron the other night.‚Äù AFL Scores: Round 16 match centres RELATED: Lions star torched for ‚Äòridiculous‚Äô arrogance  Jeremy Cameron can‚Äôt kick goals from there.Source:FOX SPORTS Former Fremantle and St Kilda coach Ross Lyon was equally as perplexed saying while playing Cameron out of position is an option if things aren‚Äôt working starting him there is a strange move. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs OK as something to go to but you‚Äôre right. You want to win the first quarter ‚Äî you win the first quarter you win 90 per cent of games‚Äù Lyon said. ‚ÄúMentally it‚Äôs not a great signal to the opposition. Jeremy Cameron‚Äôs starting on the wing the defender would go ‚ÄòThanks very much he‚Äôs out of the way he‚Äôs not in the goalscoring space‚Äô. ‚ÄúThey would have had logic behind it but it‚Äôs hard to figure it out from the outside.‚Äù Last year Cameron averaged 7.8 score involvements and 3.2 goals a game. In 2020 those numbers have dropped to 6.3 and 1.9 ‚Äî leading Brown to question if the 27-year-old has lost some of his ‚Äúedge‚Äù. North Melbourne legend David King was another to voice his concerns about Cameron being shifted up the ground. ‚ÄúI had a look at his last couple of weeks and he‚Äôs working right up the field. I don‚Äôt know (why)‚Äù King told Fox Footy on Wednesday night ‚ÄúI think Leon Cameron has to make a decision. Jeremy Cameron is their prime goalkicker he has to play in the forward line. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs the guy you‚Äôre paying $1.4 million to. He‚Äôs got to be your goalkicker he‚Äôs got to be your target. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs the one most likely to kick five or six goals in a game.‚Äù The Giants‚Äô most prolific forward has been down on form in 2020.Source:News Corp Australia The Giants made preliminary finals in 2016 and 2017 and lost the grand final in 2019 but with eight wins and seven losses this season they have been unable to build any momentum. Brown isn‚Äôt sure whether GWS knows what style of footy it wants to play anymore and believes that is partly the reason behind its 2020 woes. ‚ÄúI felt I used to know what GWS were and what they stood for but I‚Äôm watching them at the moment and I‚Äôm confused about what they‚Äôre trying to achieve‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThey used to be an attacking side they used to have great flair now they‚Äôve become a defensive side a defensive-minded down-the-line side and it isn‚Äôt suiting them. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm just confused about where they are how they‚Äôre trying to play what they‚Äôre trying to do what they‚Äôre trying to achieve.‚Äù Comments To join the conversation please Log in. headline: Jeff Horn‚Äôs trainer releases bombshell statement on Tim Tszyu fight
text: Glenn Rushton became an Australian villain on the night Jeff Horn was beaten to a pulp by Tim Tszyu ‚Äî and he‚Äôs finally unloaded. Boxing: While trainer Glenn Rushton didn't throw in the towel it appears Jeff Horn‚Äôs cornerman Adam Copland took matters into his own hands when referee Phil Austin approached the boxer's camp. Jeff Horn's trainer Glenn Rushton. Picture: Alix SweeneySource:News Corp Australia Glenn Rushton had some things to get off his chest. 2752 words worth. Strongly criticised for the way he handled Jeff Horn during his eight-round TKO defeat against Tim Tszyu in Townsville last month Rushton has provided a lengthy explanation for everything that happened ‚Äî and launched some friendly fire. Rushton continues to insist Horn wasn‚Äôt badly hurt in the fight and criticised referee Phil Austin for counting a knockdown against his man in the third round he says was a push. But the heaviest criticism was saved for a member of his own team. In a sign the Horn camp is fraying and may never be the same ‚Äî if the Queenslander opts to continue his career ‚Äî Rushton blamed cornerman and fellow fighter Adam Copland for ‚Äúending Jeff‚Äôs career‚Äù by waving the towel and ending the fight. Rushton accused Copland who fought on the undercard of being incapable of making a clear decision because he‚Äôd been ‚Äúsent to the canvas‚Äù earlier in the night. RELATED: Tszyu lines up title fight ‚ÄúThe footage appears to confirm that Adam in particular was largely responsible for ending the fight and quite possibly Jeff‚Äôs career‚Äù Rushton wrote. ‚ÄúThis was a shame as Adam had been sent to the canvas during his fight earlier in the night went to hospital the following morning and shouldn‚Äôt have even been on the apron in the first place. The fact that he was on the apron tells me that he probably wasn‚Äôt thinking clearly as he knows the rules.‚Äù Rushton also claimed Copland attempted to end Horn‚Äôs rematch against Michael Zerafa in 2019 before the Hornet launched an incredible comeback. Copland hit back on Instagram describing Rushton‚Äôs statement as a ‚Äúpost made by a man digging his own grave as a boxing trainer and trying to drag everyone down with him‚Äù. Team Horn before the fight (l-r) Stephen Edwards Adam Copland Jeff Horn Ben Horn Glenn Rushton. (Photo by Bradley Kanaris/Getty Images)Source:Getty Images ‚ÄúFor Glenn to write this about me with not one phone call to me after the fight asking why I stopped it just shows what type of person he is‚Äù Copland wrote. ‚ÄúTo say I was concussed and confused is nothing but defamatory and false. Of course I knew what was going on and so did the rest of Australia. ‚ÄúI could sit here and write 2700 words about him like he did about everyone else in his post but I think he says enough for everyone to understand who he is as a person. ‚ÄúAnd yes I called him and told him all my problems about his post before I decided to post this as that in my eyes is the right thing to do. And of course there was no acceptance of any wrong doing as usual. ‚ÄúI love Jeff Horn and his whole family. I hope the public does not associate Jeff Horn with Glenn Rushton‚Äôs garbage. As no one deserves that.‚Äù In his lengthy post on the Stretton Boxing Club Facebook page Rushton also revealed Horn‚Äôs health issues in the lead-up said his fighter‚Äôs ‚Äúflame has gone‚Äù and also criticised cutman Stephen Edwards for helping create confusion in the corner. GLENN RUSHTON‚ÄôS FULL STATEMENT Thanks again to all of our supporters out there who got behind Jeff for his fight against Tim Tszyu. Of course we‚Äôre all disappointed including Jeff. This was certainly not the same Jeff Horn who walked into the ring on that magical day just over three years ago to defeat Manny Pacquiao. Jeff is one of those people that you can‚Äôt help but like and we‚Äôve shared an incredible journey together. From the time this bullied schoolkid walked into my gym to learn self-defence when he had just turned 18 I have grown to admire him for his courage and determination. Regardless of what Jeff does in the future I‚Äôll always be there for him. And whether he chooses to retire or continue fighting I‚Äôm comfortable either way. Only Jeff can make that decision and there‚Äôs no hurry. So what went wrong in the fight against Tim Tszyu? Jeff Horn's trainer Glenn Rushton. Picture: Alix SweeneySource:News Corp Australia On the day of the fight Chris Muckert Jeff‚Äôs new strength and conditioning coach and former NRL player assured me that Jeff was ready to deliver the performance of his career. He said he had slept perfectly his recovery was phenomenal and his resting heart rate was purring along at just 39 beats a minute. Leading into the fight Jeff had done Dexa scans skin folds and he was being constantly monitored by Chris to ensure his recovery diet sleep etc. were all perfect. I do know that just over a week out from the fight Jeff called me to say he had vertigo. This on top of the raspy voice had me concerned so I suggested he visit the ENT (ear nose and throat) specialist who did the surgery on Jeff‚Äôs throat some years ago. The ENT specialist gave him the all clear to fight and slowly the vertigo subsided however the throat issue remained as everyone knows who heard him speak leading into the fight. On the night of the fight I was concerned during the warm-up. Jeff wasn‚Äôt himself. He‚Äôs normally like a junk yard dog ready to tear someone apart however his demeanour was subdued and the usual pop wasn‚Äôt in his punches. From the first round Jeff was off. Tim did exactly what I thought he‚Äôd do but Jeff just wasn‚Äôt following the strategy which is odd for Jeff. When Tim went back towards the ropes on two occasions in the first round rather than Jeff drive him onto the ropes and unload on him as planned and as he did with Pacquiao he just let him off the hook. The hunger didn‚Äôt appear to be there to stay on top of Tim. The intensity and volume of punches Jeff was supposed to be throwing on the inside weren‚Äôt happening. We‚Äôve all grown to love Jeff‚Äôs tenacity but after a few rounds it appeared as though the heart had been ripped out of Jeff Horn. The V8 engine that drives Jeff simply wasn‚Äôt there. Was it psychological ‚Äì was it biological? When he came back to the corner after each round I was looking at him very closely. I could see he wasn‚Äôt hurt nor exhausted. He just appeared lethargic frustrated disinterested. Cardio wise he was actually recovering okay between rounds but he was simply too slow in not intense enough in range and appeared more intent on just getting through the rounds as opposed to winning them. It was Tim Tszyu‚Äôs night. (Photo by Bradley Kanaris/Getty Images)Source:Getty Images Most of the rounds were very scrappy with a lot of clinching pushing and shoving and not a lot of clean punches being landed by either side ‚Äì but Jeff just wasn‚Äôt dominating as he normally does. Again this was extremely odd behaviour for Jeff as he is one of the most competitive people I‚Äôve ever known which has been one of his strongest attributes ‚Äì he just has to win whether it‚Äôs boxing poker Connect 4 or any other game. While Tim was clearly winning the fight and we wish him and his team every success for the future Jeff was not getting beaten up as some people have indicated. I have watched the fight a couple of times since without the audio on to verify this. The knockdown in round 3 was a mistake as it is clear from the replay that Jeff was simply pushed over by Tim which is what I thought on the night. Unfortunately the referee was behind Tim at the time and couldn‚Äôt see this. The only other knockdown was when Jeff took a very soft knee in round six before immediately springing to his feet. Jeff was never physically knocked to the canvas nor were there any long combinations where Jeff was getting repeatedly hit. I can assure you that Jeff took a lot less punishment in this fight than in some of his previous fights. He looked fine after the fight had no headache slept well and the day after the fight he was his normal self laughing and joking. He did not appear at all exhausted after the fight in the dressing room afterwards or at the press conference. If no medical reason emerges for his performance I can only say that the flame has gone ‚Äì at least for now. This is not unusual and many athletes just wake up one day and realise they don‚Äôt want to do it anymore. More importantly they start looking for an easier way and don‚Äôt want to do what has to be done to win at the highest level. As Muhammad Ali once famously said ‚ÄúThe fight is won or lost far away from witnesses ‚Äî behind the lines in the gym and out there on the road long before I dance under those lights.‚Äù Glenn Rushton talks with Jeff Horn between rounds against Michael Zerafa. (Photo by Bradley Kanaris/Getty Images)Source:Getty Images What drives people is different for everyone. I believe Jeff will take some time to ponder his future reflect on who he is how he wants to be remembered why he is boxing if he still enjoys it and if he has more goals he wants to achieve in boxing etc. At 32 he‚Äôs not old. As an example George Foreman started his pro career when he was 20 became world champion retired at 28 years of age after 47 fights came back ten years later at age 38 had another 34 fights and became world champion again before finally retiring when he was 48. Anything is possible if the hunger is there. With regards to the criticism being levelled at me around the stoppage I‚Äôd like to say this. You don‚Äôt stop a fight just because a boxer is losing ‚Äì you stop a fight if a boxer is injured and can‚Äôt continue or is being badly hurt by his opponent ‚Äì neither of these were the case in Jeff‚Äôs fight. If you‚Äôre losing a fight but you‚Äôre unhurt you continue searching for a way to win knowing it only takes one punch to turn a fight around. There is always a way ‚Äì it‚Äôs just a matter of finding it. In an effort to get Jeff to rediscover the Jeff Horn who beat Pacquiao I told Jeff between rounds 6 and 7 that if he didn‚Äôt show me something I‚Äôd stop the fight. This seemed to motivate him against Pacquiao (when the ref warned him) ‚Äì and he did lift in round seven after I‚Äôd said this. I also knew from his recovery between rounds that he wasn‚Äôt as tired as he appeared (his breathing was quite steady) and he certainly wasn‚Äôt badly hurt so he was okay to continue ‚Äì he just wasn‚Äôt doing enough to win ‚Äì and yet he knows how to win. Ben Horn and I were on the same page and discussed this during round eight. In the corner after round eight I knew Jeff‚Äôs career was on the line and I wanted Jeff to go out on his terms so I did something I‚Äôve never done before ‚Äì I asked him if he wanted to continue. This question was as much to quieten our corner as I was becoming increasingly concerned about the comments I was hearing in the corner as I was in Zerafa 2. I was hoping Jeff would simply nod so I could then focus on what I wanted to say to him. Instead he just shrugged his shoulders as if to say I don‚Äôt really care either way. I knew he was just annoyed with himself that he was losing the fight. Again there was no physical reason why he couldn‚Äôt continue and had this been any other fighter he would have been expected to continue ‚Äì but everyone seems intent on overly protecting Jeff. We all know it only takes one punch to turn a fight around ‚Äì or even win a fight as we recently saw when Povetkin threw one left uppercut to KO Dillian Whyte even though Povetkin had suffered two knockdowns in the previous round and looked set to be KO‚Äôd himself. It‚Äôs amazing how much energy you suddenly get from landing just one really good punch. We also saw Tyson Fury climb off the canvas after appearing unconscious and for those who can remember back to 1974 when Muhammad Ali lay on the ropes for seven rounds taking a beating only to KO George Foreman in the eighth round in the famous rope-a-dope fight. Tim Tszyu lands a shot on Jeff Horn. PICTURE: MATT TAYLOR.Source:News Corp Australia What makes boxing such an exciting sport is that anything can and does happen on a regular basis. To all those who say it was obvious Jeff couldn‚Äôt win I simply say that‚Äôs nonsense. I could show you a hundred fights where it was obvious a boxer would lose ‚Äì but won. These same people thought it was obvious Jeff was about to be KO‚Äôd by Pacquiao in round 10 and again in round 9 in Zerafa 2. Both times Jeff did the impossible and snatched victory from the jaws of defeat. These two wins have shown how much courage Jeff Horn has. He also has natural endurance. Further as I am also Jeff‚Äôs manager I knew there was no rematch clause in the contract so there would be no second chance for Jeff to redeem himself. We were all in. Another reason I asked him if he would like to do one more minute in round nine is because all through the prep we had made round nine Jeff‚Äôs best round. He was used to going flat out in round nine and I had hoped that if he knew he only had to fight for another minute he could muster the hunger to give it everything he had and hopefully land the right hand from hell that he did in his last fight. If Jeff had walked out for round 9 thinking that if he didn‚Äôt land a huge punch within the first minute I‚Äôd throw the towel in ‚Äì who knows what would have happened. And we‚Äôll never know. It may have saved his career it may not have ‚Äì who knows ‚Äì but I believed he deserved one last chance. It is not an easy decision as when a fighter wins the fighter‚Äôs great ‚Äì when a fighter loses the trainer‚Äôs at fault. This rule applies in all sports as I‚Äôm sure Anthony Seibold would agree. But if you can‚Äôt stand the heat you should stay out of the kitchen and all trainers are aware of how they‚Äôll be criticised if their fighter/team loses. Of course had I taken the easy way out and thrown the towel in against Pacquiao no one would have criticised me but Jeff‚Äôs life would have been much different to what it is now. It‚Äôs not easy to hold the faith under these trying conditions but I believe so strongly in Jeff and with his career evaporating I had to give him one last chance to snatch victory from defeat. I‚Äôm also aware that many fighters become overconfident when they‚Äôre close to victory and as a result have been KO‚Äôd. Jeff Horn looks at the referee. (Photo by Bradley Kanaris/Getty Images)Source:Getty Images We saw this in Jeff‚Äôs last fight when an overconfident Michael Zerafa snatched defeat from victory. And Tim Tszyu is only a young fighter with limited experience in big fights ‚Äì maybe just maybe he‚Äôd get careless and make a mistake. These are all of the points I considered. Let‚Äôs face it this fight against Tim Tszyu had not been a war like the fight with Pacquiao or even the fights with Terrence Crawford or Michael Zerafa. It was a messy fight with a lot of clinching and few clean punches landed. The primary concern of a referee is to prevent unnecessary damage to the boxer‚Äôs health ‚Äì and he saw no reason to stop the fight until our corner persuaded him. It was very difficult to communicate with Jeff after round eight as I had four other heads in the ring all trying to have their say whereas in Tim Tszyu‚Äôs corner there was just a very peaceful team with one trainer and a second which reminded me of when it was just Ben Horn and myself in the corner. I realise that everyone in our corner had Jeff‚Äôs best interests at heart and this is not a personal attack on them as they‚Äôve been great friends and excellent cornermen over the years ‚Äì but a corner is not a committee. There has to be a chain of command and I had said to Jeff after Zerafa 1 that the only person I would discuss a stoppage with in future was his brother Ben Horn and yet for Zerafa 2 I still had Adam Copland desperately wanting to throw the towel in while I was trying to concentrate on every detail that was unfolding before me so as to make the best possible decision. Adam apologised to me after the Zerafa 2 fight and admitted that at the time he thought Jeff was done. I felt the corner carried the baggage of the previous two fights into this one and were too quick to weaken. Again that is my humble opinion and of course everyone is entitled to their own opinion. Adam should never have been on the apron in the first place as only two seconds are allowed on the apron which in our corner was Stephen and Ben as always. Both Adam and Stephen were adamant they wanted the fight to stop. Stephen was heard saying a couple of times ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to‚Äù meaning he didn‚Äôt want Jeff to continue and Adam is telling Ben ‚Äúno‚Äù when Ben was supporting me about allowing Jeff to continue for another minute to see what he could do. Tim Tszyu hits Jeff Horn with an uppercut. Picture: Alix SweeneySource:News Corp Australia Adam can also be seen tapping the referee on the shoulder and waving with his right hand at which point the referee looks at Adam and then turns around and waves the fight off. The footage appears to confirm that Adam in particular was largely responsible for ending the fight and quite possibly Jeff‚Äôs career. This was a shame as Adam had been sent to the canvas during his fight earlier in the night went to hospital the following morning and shouldn‚Äôt have even been on the apron in the first place. The fact that he was on the apron tells me that he probably wasn‚Äôt thinking clearly as he knows the rules. I have no qualms with the referee Phil Austin as I believe he thought the corner wanted the fight stopped. Do I believe he would have stopped the fight had our corner acted differently ‚Äì no. Had my corner simply let me and me alone speak (as they usually do) I would have said to Jeff ‚ÄúJeff you‚Äôve got one minute to save your career. If you‚Äôre not clearly winning the next round within a minute I‚Äôm going to throw the towel in. Jeff there‚Äôs still time. Come on let‚Äôs give it everything you‚Äôve got for one minute.‚Äù And rest assured if he wasn‚Äôt winning after 30 seconds I‚Äôd have thrown the towel in. Jeff deserved every chance to go out a winner ‚Äì the fact he wasn‚Äôt given that one last opportunity breaks my heart. I was the person who had the most experience as well as the most information about Jeff to make the call but unfortunately I wasn‚Äôt allowed that opportunity ‚Äì and I can assure you it still hurts. Again I want to finish by saying thank you to Jeff and everyone in the team. Yes mistakes were made both during the camp and on the night but I realise that everyone in the team did what they thought was best for Jeff. Am I personally taking this loss hard ‚Äì yes because I deeply care about Jeff and I never wanted it to end like this. headline: Curtis Scott: Footage of NRL star being tasered by police revealed as all charges dismissed
text: Shocking footage of NRL star Curtis Scott being pepper sprayed and tasered by police has been played in court as charges against him were dismissed. Footage of NRL star Curtis Scott's dramatic arrest in Sydney including him being tasered by police has emerged in court as his charges were dismissed. Bodycam CCTV of Curtis Scott being arrested. Picture: Handout via NCA NewsWireSource:NCA NewsWire Dramatic footage of NRL star Curtis Scott being tasered by police has been played in court a day after a series of charges laid against him following boozy Anzac Day celebrations were sensationally dropped. Extended vision of what Scott‚Äôs lawyer claims was an ‚Äúunreasonable or unlawful‚Äù arrest underpins an application for NSW Police to pay the costs of his nine-month legal battle that total more than $100000. Magistrate Jennifer Giles accepted his guilty plea to other minor charges on Thursday but did not record a conviction. She told Downing Centre Local Court no punishment she handed down could match the events of his arrest. ‚ÄúMy client is innocent and we had to fight pretty hard and pretty long to get this decision‚Äù Scott‚Äôs lawyer Sam Macedone said outside court. Curtis Scott‚Äôs remaining charges were dismissed on Thursday. Picture: NCA NewsWire/Joel CarrettSource:News Corp Australia Scott told reporters the ordeal had been a ‚Äúreally tough time in my life‚Äù that he was hoping to put behind him although Mr Macedone said they would explore bringing a civil case against the police. It came after serious allegations of assaulting and resisting police were dropped in court on Wednesday when the first snippets of revelatory police bodycam footage showed the incident for the first time. The Canberra Raiders outside back was intoxicated and barely conscious as he was arrested just metres from NRL headquarters in Moore Park about 2.10am on January 27. How police found Curtis Scott. Picture: Handout via NCA NewsWireSource:NCA NewsWire Scott is tasered by a police officer.Source:Supplied The view from behind the taser as captured by a police body-worn camera.Source:Supplied In the extended footage played on Thursday Scott 22 was doused with capsicum spray and tasered after police found him sleeping peacefully on his back at the base of a fig tree. The clearly confused footballer can be heard telling police he was ‚Äúgetting dressed‚Äù before changing to a repeated line of ‚ÄúI‚Äôve done nothing wrong‚Äù after he was handcuffed and ordered to get to his feet. It then shows one officer deploy his taser as Scott remains on the ground handcuffed and moaning in pain after copping pepper spray in the face having resisted efforts to stand him up. ‚ÄúStop otherwise you‚Äôll be tasered‚Äù he was warned. Scott writhes and screams out in agony before falling silent when Senior Constable Chris Bucknell tells him: ‚ÄúYou lash out again I‚Äôll f***ing taser you again.‚Äù Curtis Scott recoils after being pepper sprayed.Source:Supplied Sam Macedone said he would speak to his client about a possible civil case. Picture: NCA NewsWire/Bianca De MarchiSource:News Corp Australia The footage revealed Scott was asleep when police first came across him. They tried to rouse him by pinching his ear before handcuffing him without formally placing him under arrest. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt resist mate‚Äù one of the officers says as Scott lays slumped in the roots of a fig tree his eyes closed. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve done thing wrong‚Äù Scott says before being told he is trespassing. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve done f**k all wrong.‚Äù The young rugby league star decided to leave the room on Thursday before the videos were played to the court. Mr Macedone said the ‚Äúgruesome‚Äù incident had taken a big toll on Scott. Prosecutor Sergeant Rebecca Becroft had argued against the footage being played beyond the point it was on Wednesday which did not include Scott‚Äôs tasering a move Mr Macedone later described as an attempt to ‚Äúavoid scrutiny‚Äù. The police case collapsed yesterday after Ms Giles described the police argument that the officers were within their rights to handcuff an unconscious man as ‚Äúa very long and frightening bow‚Äù. Sgt Becroft withdrew five charges on Wednesday two of assaulting police one of resisting arrest and another of indecent behaviour. Curtis Scott after playing for the Canberra Raiders. Picture: Matt Roberts/Getty ImagesSource:Getty Images But Sgt Becroft on Thursday asked Ms Giles how else police were supposed to move on a person she claimed was ‚Äúabsolutely tragically affected by drugs or alcohol‚Äù. She said the officers could have ended up in the Coroner‚Äôs Court if they left him to continue his slumber pondering whether Scott could have choked on his own vomit got into a fight or fell out onto the roadway and been hit by a car. The officers didn‚Äôt go in with ‚Äúguns blazing‚Äù she said and gave him ‚Äúample opportunity to get up and get out of there‚Äù. ‚ÄúAt the time police were acting on the circumstances they were faced with‚Äù Sgt Becroft said. She said police were being asked to foot the bill for hundreds of dollars in costs Scott‚Äôs lawyers racked up in emails and phone calls to the NRL Canberra coach Ricky Stuart and chief executive Don Furner. The costs bill also included a $3300 claim for his legal team studying US websites about tasering Sgt Becroft told the court. Curtis Scott (left) and lawyer Sam Macedone speak to media. Picture: NCA NewsWire/Bianca De MarchiSource:News Corp Australia Separate footage of Scott‚Äôs drunken night through the streets of Paddington before he settled to sleep in Moore Park was also played to the court. Scott was sentenced for two counts of offensive behaviour in public having pleaded guilty to those charges at an earlier court date. No conviction was recorded. CCTV showed him kick and stomp on a bicycle chained to a pole on Regent St. The court heard that came before he punched the driver‚Äôs side door of a taxi and threw his mobile phone at a passing Suzuki Swift. Mr Macedone said Scott had been drinking at the Ivy in Sydney‚Äôs CBD and had no recollection of how he got to Moore Park. He had not drunk for five months and was mentoring the Canberra Raiders under-16 team about the impact of alcohol the court heard. An officer speaks to Scott in the bodycam footage. Picture: Handout via NCA NewsWireSource:NCA NewsWire In dismissing the charges Ms Giles said Scott had already been punished by the intense media scrutiny surrounding the incident and stress at possibly losing his career ‚ÄúYou are clearly a smart person Mr Scott you are the kind of person on whom this experience has not been wasted‚Äù she said ‚ÄúBeing capsicum sprayed whilst you are handcuffed and not decontaminated for some 19-odd minutes that‚Äôs much worse than anything I can do to you.‚Äù Ms Giles will deliver he decision on the costs application on September 25.
